item.title: The KKR partner excited about the deal that lost $1.3bn is long gone
item.description:
It used to be that private equity offered a steady and lucrative career. As private equity firms struggle to convert historic investments into hard cash, this may no longer be the case.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Timothy Franks is one of those who had a long and lucrative career in private equity. Franks, who did not respond to an invitation to comment for this article, embarked upon his career in 1999 after a brief time in investment banking </news/what-is-an-investment-bank> at Deutsche Bank and then Credit Suisse. He became a partner at Advent International and then a partner at KKR.
One of Franks' investments while he was at KKR has this week lost $1.3bn, but he may not care. He left the fund a year after it was made.
As head of the EMEA consumer group at KKR, Franks fronted the fund's €1.1bn ($1.3bn) investment in Danish e-bike maker Accell Group in 2022. At the time, Franks seemed stoked by the opportunity. “Accell Group’s transport and mobility solutions have been a thematic investment focus for KKR for some time, and we believe that the bicycle sector and e-bikes in particular will play an increasingly important role in dealing with some of the major challenges the world is facing today...", he said three years ago, adding that KKR's investment would help Accell to realize "its full potential as a global industry leader and sustainable innovator.”
Accell did not achieve its full potential. After over-ordering inventory it faced a sales slump that threatened it with bankruptcy <https://www.ft.com/content/acd62c0a-7c99-4864-9d77-f94b66664bda> until its debts were restructured this week, resulting in KKR losing its $1.3bn investment.
The episode is a reminder that private equity is not always a one way street and that carried interest </news/private-equity-carried-interest>payments are not always forthcoming. Accell's issues began surfacing in mid-2023; Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-07-12/kkr-s-franks-departs-as-head-of-uk-and-ireland-private-equity> reported that Franks decided to leave in July of the same year for reasons that may have been coincidental.
Some of Franks' investments at KKR worked out much better. Franks also participated in KKR's purchase of a 60% stake in Wella in 2020. Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/kkr-prepares-opi-owner-wella-company-us-ipo-sources-say-2026-02-03/> reported in January that Wella is preparing for an IPO which will value Wella at far more than KKR paid for it.
After leaving KKR, Franks became CEO of "purpose driven" investment firm Jacobs Holdings, but he stepped down from that role last year. He's spoken openly about being gay and raising a family with his husband, Andrew, with whom he collects contemporary art. This is probably less stressful than selling e-bikes.

item.title: How to write a resume for a job in quant finance
item.description:
Getting a quant </news/quant-jobs-finance> job at a bank, hedge fund </news/all-the-jobs-in-hedge-funds> or trading firm </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> is an arduous process, but it'll never start if your CV </news/2022/06/banking-resume-guide> never makes it through the screening process. In such a complex and opaque industry, how do you write a resume that stands out? We've spoken to recruiters and industry insiders to find out.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
One New York headhunter, speaking anonymously, told us that the "format of the resume </news/finance/50-ways-to-improve-your-resume-to-land-a-financial-services-job> is completely irrelevant, it just needs to be clean </news/goldman-sachs-cv-template>and show quality throughout their education and work history." James Holland, director of London-based recruitment firm Quant Capital agreed. When you're writing a quant CV, Holland said: "most companies want to see clearly where you have worked and what you've been doing," he said. "This shouldn't take more than a page."
When it comes to education </news/the-20-universities-jane-street-loves-most-for-its-quants-and-engineers>, Holland said firms are paying attention to "where you've been educated, what grade you got and when you went there." How detailed you need to be varies on the role and firm you're applying for. Jane Street </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-jane-street> employees, for example, have previously suggested that the modules you choose are more important than the degree itself; you'd be wise to include them when applying to a junior role at a trading firm, but perhaps less so for a senior quantitative portfolio manager job at a hedge fund.
When it comes to technology, Holland said you should avoid listing "a million things you've only played with. Be honest about your real strengths." Don't list Python </news/programming-languages-for-a-career-in-finance> unless you can "write hardcore production Python code." An easy way to do this is by listing technologies on a role-by-role basis; Kirsty Tutton, a director at Selby Jennings, previously told us </news/2023/01/best-banking-cv-engineering> "banking clients like to see the tech stack used for each role as opposed to a big list"
Holland said "people are also looking at GitHubs </news/hedge-fund-tech-cv-interview-advice#:~:text=Going%20into%20the,your%20own%20risk.> more and more." It's becoming a necessity to include one outside of pure alpha generation </news/what-is-a-quant-researcher-hedge-fund> roles. Working on open-source projects is highly valued, but you should also include personal projects if you have any. "It gives a few more more strings to your bow and shows you're interested in what you do," he said.
As with all CVs, it's important to quantify your achievements wherever possible. This can be hard when you've worked or interned at a highly secretive firm. Speaking via an AMA in The Bubble, our new anonymous community <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/t/ama-im-a-quant-career-coach-supporting-internship-job-search-mfe-admissions/5111/11>, quant careers coach Ash Cross gave some workarounds. You can estimate the number of hours of work saved by technology you've built, talk about how widely your tools have been adopted across your business or provide percentage improvements in the accuracy and stability of your models. You should ask your former manager if you're unsure, but Cross says you should talk "about the general process and the impact you made, not the frameworks used."
Don't worry if your resume looks too vague. Holland said firms "understand the game; we're not expecting a CV that details everything and gives away the secrets." If you're being asked to disclose them in your resume or during an interview, it's a bit of a red flag.
'Interests' sections on quant CVs are a contentious topic, but can go a long way in humanizing you. Holland said that it's important that your interests are "recent, relevant and something you can talk about." For example, competitive chess </news/2022/12/how-to-get-a-trading-job-at-citadel-securities> is very popular among quants and "it's a good thing to put on there if you can genuinely talk about it... you never know who you'll meet in an interview." Interests without direct bearing on quant finance should only be mentioned if they require a high level of expertise (e.g. restoring classic cars) or if you perform at a particularly high level (e.g. professional/amateur powerlifting, as opposed to a 'Passion for fitness').

item.title: Centerview Partners' emotionally distressed analyst wants her therapist to testify
item.description:
Kathryn Shiber </news/open-ai-junior-bankers> only worked for boutique </news/boutique-investment-banks> investment bank </news/what-is-an-investment-bank> Centerview Partners for three months before she was fired, but in a New York court case whch the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/60b3dd1c-112a-470c-aa77-1bc697d13cf7>says is due to start next week, Shiber is seeking $5m in damages for - among other things - all the money she might have earned during a 10 year career there. Whether or not she succeeds may depend in part upon her therapist.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Shiber says her short time as an investment banking analyst formatting PowerPoint slides at Centerview left her with issues. Her original filing in 2021 <https://storage.courtlistener.com/recap/gov.uscourts.nysd.559015/gov.uscourts.nysd.559015.1.0_2.pdf> cites,"damages to the quality of her life, her self-esteem, self-respect and financial and emotional well-being. She says she was subjected to "humiliating and demeaning" conduct at Centervew, which will "remain a source of humiliation, distress and financial loss," for the future.
Shiber - who was already suffering from a diagnosed mood and anxiety disorder when she joined the firm aged 21, is asking her ex-therapist, Kylee Mueggenburg, to testify to the emotional distress she suffered as a result of her brief time at the boutique. Centerview, in turn, is arguing that Mueggenburg's testimony should be excluded from the trial because it says Shiber disclosed Mueggenburg's identity too late in the process. Centerview also says that Mueggenburg "blindly relied on representations made by Ms. Shiber....and did not consider alternative sources of Ms. Shiber’s alleged distress." Mueggenburg allegedly didn't even know that Shiber had lost her job, for example.
Mueggenburg - who is based in San Fransciso - describes herself <https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/therapists/kylee-mueggenburg-san-francisco-ca/1557829>as helping young adults experiencing anxiety and life transitions and passionate about helping people navigate trauma. After being fired by Centerview, Shiber worked in the finance group at Google. The FT notes that she's earned $582k in the five years since leaving the boutique.
Shiber's case hinges around whether Centerview should have made more effort to accommodate her need to sleep for at least eight hours a night to stop her anxiety from spiralling.
Shiber claims that once she started working at Centerview it became quickly apparent that "employees were expected, at times, to work 24 hours in a day or across multiple days without rest or stopping." She says that she herself worked from 8am to 1am for "two or three days in a row" during one week and that after logging off at 1am when she thought all her work was finally done, her associate reprimanded her for not informing him first. Shiber then went to HR, who arranged for her to have a "hard stop" between midnight and 9am. She proceeded to work "from 9:00 am to midnight each day, seven days a week," including a whole Labor Day weekend. She was fired around two weeks later.
If Shiber's case succeeds, other junior bankers </news/finance/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds-really> with anxiety will also be able to demand eight hours' sleep. Centerview is arguing that it doesn't owe her many millions of dollars because she only worked there briefly and "identified no evidence indicating she would have completed the three-year analyst program, let alone received a promotion to associate."
The FT notes that Centerview has also raised questions about the amount of time Shiber spent on Instagram and Tiktok.

item.title: Singapore’s home hero hedge fund picks up a Senior PM from Millennium
item.description:
Dymon Asia Capital, the Singapore-based hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> growing all over Asia </news/singapore-hedge-fund-hiring-dymon>, had a great 2025, with its multi-strategy fund returning 18% across the year. It grew across the year – and it seems to be growing into 2026, too.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Wissam Mezrani joined Dymon Asia Capital last month in Singapore as a portfolio manager, specialising in cross-asset derivative strategies. He joined the firm from Millennium, where he spent just under two years as a senior portfolio manager. Dymon does not use the "senior" PM title, although it does also operate pods, like many other multi-strategy funds </news/biggest-multistrategy-hedge-funds>.
Before joining Millennium, Mezrani spent four years at Citi in Hong Kong and then Singapore. In both markets, he was the firm’s head of quantitative market making – presumably locally. He also had stints as a trader at SocGen and Credit Suisse.
At Dymon, Mezrani will reunite with Anass Hamedi </news/dymon-capital-asia>, a fellow graduate of grande école </news/2023/02/best-grande-ecole-finance> CentraleSupélec. They worked together closely at Millennium – Hamedi was part of Mezrani’s pod – and they are working together at Dymon, too.
Dymon’s appetite for growth seems insatiable. The fund hired at least 19 portfolio managers </news/dymon-capital-asia> in 2025, as part of a 100-ish growth in headcount. It seems to be on the same path in 2026 – and with its multi-strategy fund posting a record 5% return in January 2026, things seem to be on track.

item.title: Eisler Capital's ill-fated head of HR says it was a "formative" experience
item.description:
When Joanna Hay arrived at Eisler Capital as head of HR in September 2025, she possibly thought she was joining a small but thriving hedge fund </news/finance/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>that needed to hire a few more people after its key portfolio managers ran away earlier in the year. </news/as-portfolio-managers-leave-eisler-capital-contemplation-of-bonus-clawbacks>
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Instead, Hay says she found herself "supporting the fund through its eventual unwinding." Writing on LinkedIn, Hay says this was "difficult and challenging but turned out to be one of the most positive formative experiences of my career."
Eisler Capital announced its intention to close </news/eisler-capital-hedge-fund-closing> at the end of September 2025, so Hay presumably had no more than 30 days there before the reality of her role became apparent. She says she and her team approached the process of parting company with Eisler's staff with "rigor and efficiency," and "sustained the high level of operation Eisler Capital was known for."
We haven't spoken to Eisler Capital for this article, but many of its people have since turned up elsewhere. Valdo Durrleman, </news/valdo-durrleman-brevan-howard> its second most important strat </news/eisler-capital>, has for example, recently resurfaced at Brevan Howard.
Eisler Capital has sadly become the poster child for multistrategy hedge funds </news/big-multistrategy-hedge-funds>gone wrong. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-07/eisler-lost-14-3-last-year-as-hedge-fund-firm-closed-down> reported that the fund lost 14.3% in its final year. Things deteriorated as the expense of paying portfolio managers on the pass-through model </news/hedge-fund-pass-throughs>weighed on insipid returns after all the most profitable portfolio managers escaped </news/lewis-morton-eisler>. Star performer Lewis Morton is now at Taula Capital with "humble" founder Diego Megia </news/taula-capital-hedge-fund> instead. Most people left before the end of December </news/eisler-capital-is-officially-cutting-79-people-in-new-york> and Eisler's fancy London office </news/eisler-capital-london-office>is now occupied by rival hedge fund Verition, which previously occupied the floor below and could be observed through a glass portal. To the extent that anyone is still working on the wind down, we understand that they are at home.
Meanwhile, Hay herself has got a new job. She is now head of HR at Helios Investment Partners, an African private investment firm. Other funds thinking of winding down at speed may want to bear her expertise in mind.

item.title: JPMorgan trader suffered "dehumanising travel experiences" as a result of her disability
item.description:
One of the benefits of working at a bank like JPMorgan </news/jpmorgan-pub>is that it's a global institution, and you have the opportunity to move to a new city for work. When you suffer from a disability </news/2022/08/work-in-ma-chronically-tired>, this benefit comes with a lot of costs; Julie Andrieu, an exotics trader </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank> at JPMorgan, said she experiences "dehumanising travel experiences several times a year" as a result of poor accomodation for her spinal muscular atrophy.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Andrieu works in JPMorgan's London office, having moved there from France after completing a masters in financial engineering (MFE) </news/top-masters-in-financial-engineering-courses> in 2022. She "travel[s] regularly between London and the South of France to see [her] family" but said that she has had to raise formal complaints with Heathrow Airport multiple times over her treatment. This week, she said she took a British Airways flight back to London and had to wait in the plane for an hour "because no ramp had been organised to retrieve my wheelchair from the hold, despite the cabin crew proactively alerting ground staff in advance." When she got off the plane, the assistance staff "were so poorly trained that they nearly dropped me."
Andrieu said she now dreads flying, "not because of turbulence, but because of systems that consistently fail disabled passengers." This isn't just problematic for her personal life; Andrieu said that disabled people "want to travel for business. We want to lead companies. We want to contribute to economic growth." A lack of accommodation for their needs obstructs this. British Airways did not respond to a request for comment.
In 2024, Andrieu was named a disability champion by JPMorgan and praised for her efforts to help hire disabled students. The bank has been quietly distancing itself from DEI practices in recent years, but this has usually been in relation to gender or ethnic diversity criteria </news/diversity-hiring-banks>. The bank's decision to bring staff into the office 5 days per week </news/jpmorgan-remote-work-banking> has been criticised for its lack of inclusiveness for disabled staff, but in Jamie Dimon's famous rant </news/jamie-dimon-work-from-home> against hybrid work, he did admit that the bank had learned "flexibility" over covid. "Particularly for, it’s usually women, caregivers, we understand there will be flexibility," he said.

item.title: Morning Coffee: JPMorgan's junior bankers lost some perks, gained a "transcendental experience." RBC's equities hiring spree
item.description:
If you're a junior banker at JPMorgan in New York, you won't have to wait decades for the sort of spiritual revelation that hedge fund founder Bobby Jain </news/as-jain-global-p-ms-take-headhunter-calls-bobby-jain-explains-why-they-need-patience>says should be your focus from the age of 80. Instead, you can take the elevator to floor 13 and see the face of Jamie Dimon in a pint of Guinness.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
This is the sort of thing that the Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/banking/jpmorgan-opened-a-bar-for-employees-if-only-they-could-get-in-d60e215f>says takes place in the "English pub" at JPMorgan's newly constructed New York office. </news/jpmorgan-office-park-avenue>Dimon's Guinness showing was not a visitation but the work of a machine that impressed his features on the foam as a joke. Even so, it's "transcendental" up there in the words of JPMorgan's head of real estate. There are "captivating sunsets" and reminders that even in a $3bn steel tower you're at the mercy of the natural world: gales whistle past the windows, which shake in their (bronze) casings.
All of this sounds very fine for a 25 year-old banker seeking more than spreadsheets. Unfortunately, the WSJ says it's also not easy to get into JPMorgan's portal of pints. The English pub in the sky at JPMorgan tends to be filled with senior bankers and their clients; if you want to go, you need to book a slot well in advance.
Difficulties getting into the pub matter, because although JPMorgan's new office has a signature smell and an interstellar entrance hall, the new building has coincided with niggles that could be smoothed by a pint in the clouds. The gym </news/jp-morgan-park-avenue-office> there comes with a fee. The workstations are crowded </news/jpmorgan-office-park-avenue>. JPMorgan managing directors who had their own offices at Madison Gardens now share small offices and are expected to sit on open-plan floors. And the JPMorgan junior bankers - who were previously able to work from home and expense meals in the evenings, can now expense meals only if they're in the office late, and must use the cheapest cabs when they leave.
Transcendence is therefore needed. But there are 10,000 people working at JPMorgan's Park Avenue office and 55 places in the pub. Only the select will make it in.
Separately, another Canadian bank is going big on electronic equities. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-18/rbc-hires-goldman-trader-noel-reyes-in-equity-algorithm-push?taid=6996439f07ae960001a1d98a&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter&sref=DK3y4h9m>reports that RBC has hired Noel Reyes from Goldman Sachs, plus "at least eight" other senior equities professionals since July.
Reyes is a big catch. He was previously head of Americas electronic trading product at Goldman Sachs. Before that, he was head of Americas execution services product at JPMorgan.
Perfecting the art of electronic trading is often allied to targeting hedge fund clients. TD Securities has also spent the last few years building out an electronic trading business. Reyes presumably received a big inducement to leave big American banks for RBC.
Meanwhile...
Wall Street bankers account for 50% of Hampton's house price purchases and now that bonuses are paid they want a weekend retreat. (NY Post) <https://nypost.com/2026/02/18/business/wall-street-bonus-bonanza-fuels-hamptons-spending-spree-sending-east-end-home-prices-soaring-33/>
Brevan Howard's crypto fund lost 30% last year. The Brevan Howard Master Fund gained 4% in January, though. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/8fc6edbb-adb8-46a2-84f4-e2b0bbc50aa2>
David Solomon at Goldman Sachs owns some bitcoin. He says he is mostly an observer of the asset. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-18/goldman-ceo-solomon-long-a-crypto-skeptic-says-he-owns-bitcoin?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260218&utm_campaign=author_21835441>
Hollyport Capital, a private equity firm focused on secondaries, wants to sell itself for $1bn. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-18/uk-private-equity-firm-hollyport-hires-evercore-to-explore-sale?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260218&utm_campaign=author_20677156>
KKR spent €1.1bn to acquire electronic bike maker Accell after the pandemic. Now it's worth nothing at all. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/acd62c0a-7c99-4864-9d77-f94b66664bda>
How to prepare for an AI interview: Record yourself answering six to eight common question. Review the recording on mute, just watching your presence and body language. Listen to the audio only focusing on pacing, filler words and clarity. Then watch the whole thing. (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/tech/ai/job-interview-tips-ai-a3be8593?mod=e2tw>
Glitches in videos stop you getting hired. Most damaging are: distortion, lags, sustained video loss, echoes or brief freezes, audio drops. (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/lifestyle/careers/video-glitch-job-interview-88925b93?mod=e2tw>
Working for AI start-ups is a nightmare. 16 hour days, six days a week. (Guardian) <https://www.theguardian.com/technology/ng-interactive/2026/feb/17/ai-startups-work-culture-san-francisco>

item.title: What is private credit? What are private credit jobs?
item.description:
Much has been said about private credit </news/search?search=private%20credit>. Since the pandemic it's been the part of the financial services industry that everyone wants to work in, based on growth of around 50% since 2020 - from $2tn to $3tn - according to Morgan Stanley <https://www.morganstanley.com/ideas/private-credit-outlook-considerations>.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Private credit owes its expansion to the restrictions on lending by banks. After Basel III, banks faced significant restrictions on capital and liquidity. Many banks found it simpler to discard riskier and illiquid loans to maintain their benchmarks, but those loans were still a ripe target market for an investor with the right approach to risk and/or liquidity.
Unlike private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity>, the private part of private credit doesn’t come from the customer/target company. It comes from the credit firm itself, which lends private capital to both private and public companies.
Private credit is a rapidly growing industry, even now. From $40bn in assets under management (AuM) in 2000, it had almost $2tn in late 2025, according to HSBC <https://www.business.hsbc.com/en-gb/insights/market-and-regulatory-insights/private-credit-unlocked-new-growth-engine-in-finance>, which also forecast that it could reach $4.5tn in AuM by 2030. The sky is the limit for private credit – or, at the very least, the $141tn global fixed income market is the limit.
So, how does it all work? A Morgan Stanley <https://www.morganstanley.com/ideas/private-credit-outlook-considerations> report from October last year noted that there are five “types” of private credit: direct lending, mezzanine capital, distressed debt, special situations, and asset-backed finance.
What is direct lending?
Direct lending is what most people think of when they hear about private credit. In a nutshell, it’s a non-bank institution (the private credit firm) making a loan to another company.
It’s an alternative to that company going through a bank’s debt capital markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm> team to issue a tradable public debt, and it’s an option usually taken by a company that would have otherwise only qualified to be “non-investment grade”, in Morgan Stanley’s words. In other words – it’s often a loan taken by companies that wouldn’t get a good deal on the public markets due to their poor record.
Direct lending jobs are pretty similar to ones in leveraged finance - analysing EBITDA and leverage ratios to determine the price/quality of a loan. The main difference being that, instead of pitching it to investors (in a syndicate), a direct lending professional is pitching it to their investment committee.
What is mezzanine capital?
Mezzanine capital is a long-term loan arrangement with a special privilege – in the event of a company going into bankruptcy, it is one of the first loans to be paid off. It is often also convertible into equity.
The fact that mezzanine capital is convertible into equity means that the job is pretty familiar to any banker that's worked on convertible bonds.
What is distressed debt?
Distressed debt lending is given to companies in financial distress, with the aim to restructure their balance sheet. As one may expect, this sort of activity is more common during economic downturns and what Morgan Stanley calls “periods of credit tightness”. As you might expect, lending to companies on the brink of financial failure is high risk and high reward.
Distressed debt lending is a place for the restructuring bankers of the world. The depth of analysis needed - as well as the typical target market - means that these have some significant overlap. Fintech CAIS notes <https://www.caisgroup.com/articles/an-introduction-to-distressed-debt-and-credit-investing> that "Distressed funds have been formed to buy this debt, take borrowing companies through a capital restructuring."
Naturally, distressed debt also requires lawyers. Firms teetering (or totally) over the edge of bankruptcy, especially financial services firms, have complex hierarchies of debt repayment that require bulletproof legal knowledge to maximise value extraction.
What is special situations?
This is essentially lending to a company that is in a pickle. It doesn’t have to be a bad pickle – it’s not distressed debt – but it is a pickle requiring bespoke credit arrangements. The examples that Morgan Stanley gives are companies actively amid an M&A transaction, divesture, or spin-off driving their borrowing needs.
Special situations lending is something that banks have dabbled in historically. At Goldman Sachs </news/how-to-get-a-job-goldman-sachs>, this business was run by Julian Salisbury </news/2023/01/goldman-sachs-partner-how-i-moved-out-of-the-middle-office> at one point (he moved on to running the merchant bank after that). Salisbury moved to private investment firm Sixth Street in 2024. Nowadays, mostly hedge funds are involved in special situations investing - and they tend to hire credit analysts (or traders) for the role.
The work of restructuring professionals also overlaps with special situations, too. Boutique bank </news/boutique-investment-banks> PJT Partners, for example, lumps the two into the same team <https://www.pjtpartners.com/expertise/restructuring-special-situations>.
What is asset-backed finance?
Asset backed finance is a lending arrangement based on specific future revenues. That can mean a specific loan to buy a piece of real estate, a plane, or even a pool of financial assets such as student loans.
Asset-backed finance is something that banks do pretty regularly in their "normal" activities - it's a pretty standard corporate loan, in fact. Structured finance teams might feel more at home here than others, too, on account of their creative use of asset pools to create collateral for loans.
What is private credit’s outlook?
Private credit might have peaked. The Financial Times reported <https://www.ft.com/content/c071fa65-5517-4224-90c9-d73718165367> in January that private credit firms were selling their investments to themselves at “record rates” - around $15bn in credit continuation deals across 2025, up significantly from the $4bn across 2024.
It’s a bit of a worrying trend, and reminiscent of the ballooning secondaries market in private equity, which reached around $226bn in 2025. Boutique </news/boutique-investment-banks> bank Evercore noted <https://pe-insights.com/private-secondaries-hit-record-226bn-as-liquidity-demand-reshapes-market/> that it was a 41% increase on the year before.
There’s also the “SaaSpocalypse”. Earlier this year, there was a wave of defaults on private credit loans made to software companies, whose valuations were significantly (negatively) impacted by the emergence of AI. Private credit firms such as Blue Owl and Ares </news/ares-blue-owl-carlyle-results> saw huge one-day drops in their share price - 9% and 13% respectively - as a result.
Still, investors are looking to put money into private credit. A separate Morgan Stanley paper <https://www.morganstanley.com/im/publication/insights/articles/article_evolutionofdirectlending.pdf> last year said that 53% of institutional investors planned to increase their allocation to private credit, and only 1% planned to decrease their allocation in 2024. Just two years prior, those numbers were 48% and 7%, respectively.
What do private credit jobs pay?
Private credit pays well. Last year </news/private-credit-equity-pay>, a survey by finance influencer Litquidity <https://litquidity.co/> showed that normal compensation – salaries and bonuses combined – at private credit firms ranged between $152k and $597k, depending on role and seniority. It was more or less on par with equivalent rank pay in private equity.
As anyone who knows will tell you, however, the real money in private capital is in carried interest </news/what-is-carried-interest>. This is a pre-agreed percentage of a successfully exited deal that is paid to the professionals that worked on it. It exists in private credit, equity, and even venture capital </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-venture-capital>.
Private credit carried interest is hefty. A recent survey from search firm Heidrick & Struggles found that </news/private-equity-credit-pay> the average principal working in a direct lending fund could expect to generate €2.4m ($2.9m) in carried interest for themselves across its five-ish years life cycle. A partner in direct lending generated about €3.2m ($3.8m), and a managing partner around €7.8m ($9.2m). All big sums of money – and all well below what their peers at a buyout (private equity) fund earned in their carry, on average.

item.title: Citadel Securities is growing its rates business with a Squarepoint Capital trading head
item.description:
Citadel Securities </news/citadel-securities-vs-jane-street> has been making inroads into the rates trading market, particularly by expanding its team in Europe. </news/citadel-securities-keeps-ingesting-europe-s-top-rates-traders>The electronic market maker is also hiring rates professionals in the US, including a former hedge fund </news/all-the-jobs-in-hedge-funds> trading head in New York.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Andrew Buonauro has joined Citadel Securities as a fixed income execution strategist working across US treasuries, swaps and investment grade credit. He was most recently at quant </news/quant-jobs-finance> fund Squarepoint, where he was global head of high-touch trading, but left the fund last May. Since then, he has been working as a self-employed investment manager.
Buonauro worked across various asset classes with Squarepoint but has a rates trading background; he spent four years trading a BlueCrest </news/bluecrest-london-pay>. He also worked at macro hedge fund Element Capital as a director for five years.
Citadel Securities made various additions to its rates team last year, including Goldman Sachs MD Keith Cynar and Morgan Stanley MD Jordan Brink, who were hired in March <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-03-20/citadel-securities-poaches-from-banks-to-run-us-rates-sales-team> to run US rates sales.
The firm isn't just hiring senior rates people. It also has a trading internship open in its European rates business, available in either London or Paris; Bunoauro proposed to his wife <https://www.insideweddings.com/weddings/fairy-tale-castle-wedding-tuscany-italy/53919#:~:text=Andrew%20proposed%20to,she%20said%20yes.> outside the Eiffel Tower, so may want to visit the latter office if he ever gets nostalgic.

item.title: Bobby Jain suggests investors & portfolio managers at his hedge fund need patience
item.description:
When we suggested yesterday </news/jain-global-exoduspoint> that hedge fund Jain Global's </news/jain-global> teething problems might one day disappear in the way that ExodusPoint's have done, we didn't know that Jain Global founder Bobby Jain had given a long and meandering interview <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mWSQQcEiGbY>on the fund's evolution two days previously. Jain's message is effectively, "patience."
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
This needs to be reinforced, because for the moment some headhunters inform us that Jain's portfolio managers </news/2023/09/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund> appear open to taking their calls. "It's very easy to get into conversations with them," one headhunter tells us, speaking anonymously. "They don't desperately want to move but they're frustrated." Other recruiters echo this. Morgan Stanley's ex-head of European credit trading left earlier this month </news/morgan-stanley-s-european-head-of-credit-trading-left-jain-global> for reasons unknown.
Jain Global has so far produced only weak returns. The fund only began trading in July 2024, and generated half year returns of 0.5%. Last year, it generated returns of 3.7%. When portfolio managers are paid 20% of their pnl, this matters. It doesn't help that assets under management per employee <https://rupakghose.substack.com/p/jain-global-getting-past-the-j-curve?utm_source=substack&publication_id=1898843&post_id=188036666&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share&triggerShare=true&isFreemail=true&r=qrn8&triedRedirect=true> at Jain Global are also low compared to Schonfeld or ExodusPoint (but are on a par with Millennium and Balyasny).
However, as we noted yesterday, things could change. ExodusPoint also generated poor returns for a few years following its inception; last year, it was one of the industry's top performers.
Speaking on the Capital Allocators podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mWSQQcEiGbY>, Bobby Jain said that Jain Global has been carefully constructed so that it can easily scale. While most funds launch with a focus on one or two strategies, Jain Global launched with seven. These are and were: fundamental, quantitative and arbitrage in the equities business; rates, macro and credit in fixed income; plus Asia, which Jain says covers Korea, China, onshore, offshore China, Japan, India, and is a strand of its own. This makes it easier to grow. You're starting off as "seven-legged stool," not adding legs as you go along.
Jain Global has also invested heavily in its own infrastructure. Jain said the fund was assisted in this by AI, which meant it didn't have to hire "hundreds of technology people." While rival hedge funds are dealing with the nightmares of legacy code </news/hedge-fund-technology-jobs>, Jain said his fund has a tech stack that's fresh and new. This is a huge advantage. Jain said the head of a rival fund informed him that he too often wants to start from scratch, but is beleaguered by "legacy systems...legacy architecture, legacy people, legacy processes, legacy mindsets."
As Jain Global gets going, its founder therefore insists that his fund is primed to thrive. "You're going to see the operating leverage start kicking in because we think we can get to two, three times the size without having to hire that many more people." This would be good news for investors, and for current employees.
Jain Global launched with $5.3bn in Capital and Bobby Jain told the podcast it took 15-18 months to deploy it. "Now you have a little bit of scarcity of capital," he added, meaning that its portfolio managers are competing for existing allocations. Singapore's GIC is pulling $250m <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-13/singapore-s-gic-pulls-250-million-from-hedge-fund-jain-global>from the fund, but rivals suggest Jain could yet benefit from investors' appetite f </news/hedge-fund-hiring-2026>or allocating money to hedge funds while rivals like Citadel <https://www.cnbc.com/2025/12/23/citadel-to-return-5-billion-in-profit-to-investors-source-says.html> are returning money to investors.
It appears to be a chicken and egg situation, however. In January this year, Jain Global lost 0.9% and last year's returns were diluted by around $500m of costs <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-15/jain-hedge-fund-costs-cut-into-750-million-profits-last-year>relating to 'front loaded' expenses, which could put investors off. Jain says front-loaded costs are all part of the plan, though. "One of the things my dad said is 'take the pain upfront,'" he said. It's not chicken and egg, it's "just chicken," he added. "You have to build it all off your own balance sheet and then the money comes in....I was prepared for all that."
While some of Jain's portfolio managers chat to headhunters, others say they're more than happy there. "I think any PM that is underperforming will be talking to headhunters," says one. "This is true of any funds and not specific to Jain. I think the culture at Jain is very strong and most PMs at least the performing ones are going to stick around because of their loyalty to Bobby," he adds.
Jain Global's PMs have a few other inducements to prevent them from acting on headhunter conversations. Bobby Jain implies that he doesn't have a strict approach to drawdowns in the style of Millennium: at Jain Global, he says it's about pre-and post mortems of trades, implying discussion instead of automatic exits.
Jain says he's about talent development rather than hiring and firing. "My real business proposition is talent acceleration and taking good people and making them great," he informs the podcast. Bobby declares that he's interviewed over 200 risk takers during his career and says he's after the "35-year-old-killers" who just need someone in their corner in order to perform, plus the steady producers too. He says that you can tell whether portfolio managers are any good by how they discuss risk: "Some people when they lost money, they start using the passive tense. So when they talk about making money, they use the active tense. When they start talking about the winning trades, they talk about clever they were."
Many of the portfolio managers at Jain Global therefore seem likely to be ambitious but clear-headed 35-year-olds whom 55-year-old Bobby Jain is mentoring himself. If they only ignore the headhunters, they could make big money. Jain Global is already achieving lift off, insists Bobby: "As you get more data...as you get more experience, that all gets better and it gets better every day and the teams get more comfortable with each other every day. And I feel that palpably."
Bobby Jain himself is clearly determined to see his construction fly, even though he says his parents recommended a different tempo for later life. "They taught us from the age of 5 to 20, focus on education, 20 to 35, focus on career, 35 to 50, focus on family, 50 to 65 on service, 65 to 80 on philanthropy, 80 to 95 on spiritualism," he told the podcast, before observing that the time frames don't have to be exact.

item.title: Bank of America's most glamorous TikTok banker is not in banking
item.description:
It can be tough to lose your job as a banker </news/the-investment-banking-recruitment-process>. Aside from the money, you also have the embarrassment of admitting it to everyone. Luckily, sometimes your bank offers you a new job in the middle- or back-office </news/2023/02/middle-market-banking-jobs> – and you can keep telling people you work at an investment bank.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*1pnlzt2*_gcl_au*MzI2ODY3NDA4LjE3Njk0MTgyODM.*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NzE0MTExMjYkbzQ4NSRnMSR0MTc3MTQxNDUzNCRqNjAkbDAkaDEzMzQ5NTUwNzY.>✍️
Take Juliet Mackay, for example. Better as TikToker “notbadjuju” <https://www.tiktok.com/@notbadjuju?lang=en>, Mackay has hundreds of videos posted on her account (and on her Instagram <https://www.instagram.com/julietmackayy>). Many videos show the brutal working hours that an investment bank expects of you – she has more than one recent video where she finishes work after midnight.
There is one caveat, however. Mackay is registered with FINRA as <https://files.brokercheck.finra.org/individual/individual_7144638.pdf> working at BofA Securities since 2020, after her internship in 2019, but she hasn’t been registered with FINRA as a broker (as all investment bankers are) since May 2025. One midnight TikTok was posted in November 2025, six months after she was de-registered.
Bank of America declined to comment for this article. While Mackay still has a job with the bank, it seems that it's a non-regulated one, such as a middle-office role in compliance </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-compliance> or risk </news/risk-job-investment-bank>. It’s likely she was moved to this role around the time that BofA was making cuts last year </news/bank-of-america-cuts-analysts-associates>, when it “redeployed” some junior bankers to support roles.
These support roles are much less demanding (and less prestigious and well-paid) than actual investment banking roles, so who knows why Mackay is working until so late – maybe she’s trying to get a registered role again. Maybe it’s old content from when she was still in investment banking.
Curiously, the terminology on Mackay’s videos changed some time before she stopped being a banker. On the 11th of March, she posted content <https://www.tiktok.com/@notbadjuju/video/7480613989546741022?lang=en> describing her life as an “investment banker”. Just five days later, she posted a video <https://www.tiktok.com/@notbadjuju/video/7482526024840924446?lang=en> noting that she “worked in finance at an investment bank”. Her content is still peppered with carefully chosen uses of those two phrases – “how to break into investment banking”, and “South African working at an investment bank”.
Either way, if her working hours are correct and assuming a 9am start time, she works around 15 hours a day, or 75 hours a week, not including weekends – the sort of lifestyle </news/banking-jobs-with-the-best-lifestyle> one expects an actual banker to have, not someone in compliance or risk. “Honestly, I’ve basically spent the last five years eating dinner at my desk lol” Mackay captioned one video <https://www.tiktok.com/@notbadjuju/video/7572802604024024351?lang=en>. She might reasonably consider herself overworked.

item.title: The elite graduates earning "insane" salaries in electronic trading are not who you think
item.description:
Some elite graduates in finance come from the Grandes Ecoles </news/2023/02/best-grande-ecole-finance>. Others study in Russia </news/best-university-for-quant-finance-career>. The most prestigious of all, however, may study at Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs). These universities are seen as a cheap source of talent by banks and tech firms, with their average graduate salaries being as little as $19k. However, a select few of their top students earn more than 20 times this in electronic trading </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay>.
An ex-high-frequency trader, speaking anonymously, tells us that there are "five firms recruiting very aggressively from IITs... there's a war for talent." An IIT graduate, also speaking off-record, said that "proprietary trading </news/prop-trading-workplace-culture-inappropriate-flirting-bullying> in particular seems to have grown significantly in popularity" among graduates </news/finance-grad-job-uk> in the last decade.
Which firms are hiring? Tower Research Capital's founder Mark Gorton was hiring IIT graduates as early as 2007 <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2007-03-23/lime-s-gorton-trades-fast-seeks-car-free-utopia> for his other venture, LimeWire. Optiver opened a Mumbai office last year <https://optiver.com/about-us/locations/mumbai/#:~:text=in%202024%2C%20we%20opened%20our%20eleventh%20global%20office%20in%20this%20vibrant%20metropolis>, while fellow Amsterdam-based trading firm IMC plans to grow its Indian contingent to 150 <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/global-trading-giants-step-up-india-presence-fuelling-talent-rush-exchange-2025-06-20/> by the end of this year. Jane Street </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-jane-street> hires IIT graduates, although most of its traders in the Indian markets operate out of Hong Kong and Singapore. </news/singapore-s-finance-jobs-vs-hong-kong>
Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2025-07-06/india-gets-tough-on-high-frequency-trading-with-jane-street-crackdown> reported last July that over 1,000 math and engineering prodigies work in quant finance under one roof: The Two Horizon Centre in Gurugram. It's home to Tower Research, local firms like Quadeye, and Citadel Securities.
Like the Grandes Ecoles </news/grandes-ecoles-graduate-salaries>, IITs have a vigorous entrance exam, with the highest performers being sent to the top schools. The IIT graduate said that this exam "selects strongly for performance under pressure, speed, focus and competitiveness." Top performers are generally sent to the oldest schools: Bombay, Delhi, Kanpur, Madras and Kharagpur. The graduate we spoke said these schools "historically placed the most candidates in quant </news/quant-jobs-finance>finance... firms usually recruit based on individual performance, but those schools offer the strongest talent pool." On LinkedIn, major trading firms and hedge funds currently employ over 680 graduates from those five schools alone. Senior figures include Delhi graduate Umesh Subramanian, the CTO of hedge fund Citadel, who stepped down earlier this year. Tower Research's global head of FX trading, Ebenezer Raj, is an IIT Kharagpur graduate.
The graduate said that there isn't much specialized education for quant finance at IITs, however. AI and machine learning resources are similar to what's on offer globally.
An employment report from IIT Bombay said that, in the 2023/24 academic year, 113 out of 1475 graduates went into finance across 33 companies; the average salary overall was ~$19.7k, but the high-frequency trader said "salaries are insane now" for quants. "You can earn five times more than Google would pay for students from the same school," he said. One IIT graduate at Jane Street </news/this-is-what-it-takes-to-get-a-64k-jane-street-internship>was offered compensation of $508k in Hong Kong back in 2024 </news/jane-street-student-salaries>, for example.
Even interns </news/hedge-funds-with-graduate-training-programmes> are paid well; the trader tells us IIT graduates have been offered as much as $20k per month to intern in electronic trading (not including sign-on bonuses). This is the going rate at IMC Trading in the US, according to verified offers on Levels.fyi. <https://www.levels.fyi/internships/IMC-Trading/Software-Engineer-Intern/#:~:text=APPLY-,Summer%202026,-Chicago%2C%20IL>
India has been the hottest topic in electronic trading since regulator SEBI accused Jane Street of manipulating the equities market </news/jane-street-india-options> with one of its options strategies. Despite a broad crackdown and increases in regulation <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-10-16/india-market-regulator-to-upgrade-hft-rules-to-ensure-fair-play>, IIT hiring is ongoing; Jane Street reportedly <https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/business/markets/jane-street-continues-to-hire-at-iits-despite-ongoing-regulatory-proceedings-report-13823386.html> hired graduates from IIT Bombay, Delhi and Madras to join in 2026.

item.title: An HSBC MD accepted a demotion for a better bank in Paris
item.description:
It takes a degree of bad luck to be caught up in a restructuring that wipes out your department. And – while no one would blame you for it – finding a new job is an urgent priority. Even if it means taking a step back in your career.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Edouard de Vitry joined Bank of America in Paris this month, as a managing director </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> (MD) covering the Financial Institutions Group (FIG) in M&A </news/what-are-ma-jobs> in France.
He joined BofA from HSBC, where he spent 12 years across Paris, Brussels, Amsterdam and London, and where he was an MD covering FIG in France and Belgium, among others. At HSBC, he led HSBC’s FIG M&A efforts in the French speaking region.
De Vitry's new role looks like a demotion. Before joining HSBC, he spent 16 years at UBS, where he was, between 2008 and 2013, co-head (and at one point, sole head <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/edouard-de-vitry-ubs-fig-20110901>) of FIG for the entirety of the EMEA region. His departure was part of a high-level restructuring of the bank by Andrea Orcel, Reuters reported <https://www.reuters.com/article/business/ubs-financial-services-co-head-de-vitry-to-leave-sources-idUSBRE91B1A6/> at the time.
HSBC has been restructuring too: the British bank announced plans </news/hscb-closure-europe-us-job-cuts> to shut down its entire M&A presence in both Europe and the Americas last year, months after some talk about “thoughtful” job cuts </news/hsbc-apply-for-own-job>.

item.title: The worst paying bank in London is paying a little more
item.description:
If you want a large bonus </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank> relative to your salary, you probably do not want to work for a British bank. While Goldman Sachs has granted itself </news/bonus-cap>the ability to pay bonuses of up to 25X salaries </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank>in London, Barclays and HSBC are stuck at up to 10X. And even this looks good compared to Lloyds and NatWest, which are only paying up to 8X salaries as bonuses this year.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Lloyds released its Pillar 3 document showing its compensation for material risk takers today. In the investment bank, Lloyds paid its 46 material risk takers (MRTs) average salaries of £383k and average bonuses of £348k, leading to total compensation of £730k ($991k). Average MRT bonuses at Lloyds investment bank were up 24% on the previous year. Lloyds remains, however, the worst paying large bank in London on this measure.
NatWest released similar documents for its material risk takers last week. In the investment bank, it paid 102 MRTs average salaries of £498k and average bonuses of £396k. Bonuses in NatWest's investment bank were, however, down on the £412k it paid last year.
Both NatWest and Lloyds paid far less than Barclays </news/barclays-bonuses-2026>. Barclays' investment bank is far larger and its largesse is greater too.
Following regulatory changes </news/banking-bonuses-london>, banks in London were free to define fewer people as material risk takers and to defer a smaller proportion of MRT bonuses this year. There's little sign of this happening, however. Lloyds said today that it's still paying the sorts of role based allowances that were used to bump up salaries in the old days of the 2x EU bonus cap. It's also still defining everyone earning over £660k as a material risk taker and it's still limiting immediately available cash bonuses to £2k.
Lloyds has aspirations to expand its investment bank. The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/4da033d5-1ad8-474b-b85f-c0ebe9189b27>noted a few weeks ago that it wants to grow in FX hedging and bond sales.

item.title: Morning Coffee: HSBC MD discovers extremely cheap method of travelling to office. M&A bankers reminded that deals are difficult things
item.description:
In the world of investment banking </news/what-is-an-investment-bank>, “doughnutting” is something you don’t want to happen to you; it’s slang for giving someone a zero bonus. </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank> And apparently, in the world of train travel, it’s also a bit of a dirty word, describing the practice of buying two tickets, one for a short journey starting at your local station, and another for a short journey ending at your destination. This allows you to fool the ticket barriers at both ends while leaving a ticketless “hole” in the middle of your commute.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Over the course of a year, Joseph Molloy <https://www.thetimes.com/uk/crime/article/ex-city-banker-sentenced-dodging-train-fares-m9j82sw9p>, the former head of passive equity <https://etfexpress.com/2015/03/23/joseph-molloy-joins-hsbc-global-asset-management-head-passives/> at HSBC Global Asset Management, managed to save £5.9k ($8k) in fares by using this technique to journey from his £2m home in Kent to the office in Canary Wharf, before being caught. Molloy has now been given a suspended sentence and a community service order, as well as being banned from Southeastern Trains for a year. (That would be pretty inconvenient <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-07-29/hsbc-asks-managing-directors-to-work-in-office-four-days-a-week> now that HSBC is asking its Managing Directors to come into the office four days a week, but fortunately, Molloy retired from the job last year).
There’s a terrible kind of irony to this crime. As an index portfolio manager, Molloy would have been responsible for risk analysis and optimisation all the time in his day job. And at the same time, he seems to have identified a systematic source of alpha and worked through considerable difficulties in execution (he had to give two false addresses to register smartcard keys, as well as benefiting from a discount usually given to the unemployed). He made a profit, but was then undone by a risk which could have been called a “black swan”, except that it's the obvious one of being caught.
Molloy, who is reportedly an upstanding individual in every other way, now very much regrets what might have seemed like a fantastic trade at the time. He even changed his clothes and jumped over a wall to try to avoid being spotted leaving the court. It’s unlikely that he will work in finance again. The downside appears to have been substantial, and the risk/reward ratio must have been terrible.
Of course, when someone with plenty of money does something so obviously wrong over a comparatively trivial sum of money, there might be other things in the background. Molloy’s lawyer suggests that his balance of mind was disturbed by stress and bereavement. But whether it was an act out of character or just a catastrophic failure of common sense, there’s a cautionary tale for all quants here; the risk that does the damage is almost always the one which wasn’t in any spreadsheet.
Elsewhere, the Warner Brothers deal has now reached the “put up or shut up <https://www.ft.com/content/251fec8a-b4ea-44e7-abd2-e471f268e3a8>” stage, with Paramount being given seven days <https://www.wsj.com/business/media/warner-reopens-talks-with-paramount-after-sweetened-offer-3dbf191b?st=Zf5PAw&reflink=desktopwebshare_permalink> to come up with a “best and final” bid in opposition to Netflix. Bankers who had their Christmas ruined </news/warner-bros-acquisition-netflix-paramount-investment-bankers> working on this deal might be forgiven for wondering why nobody thought of asking this question earlier on in the process and saving a lot of time and hassle.
The answer is, of course, that you can’t save time and hassle in big M&A </news/get-a-job-in-ma> deals. The expense, inconvenience and drama are what keeps everyone honest. If the advisors had asked for “best and final offers” back in December, the offers they received would not only not be the best, they wouldn’t be final. (Netflix has said that their current bid is final, but we’ll see whether that’s true if Paramount tops it).
As the saying goes, ninety percent of the work in an M&A deal is done in fifty per cent of the time allowed, while the remaining ten per cent takes another ninety per cent. There are always false conclusions, head fakes and final opportunities, and the skill of a top M&A banker is to understand when it’s actually time to bring things to a close.
Meanwhile …
Matt Simonette, a commodities trader who has just moved from ExxonMobil to BlueCrest, is also a coffee afficionado who founded a chain of gourmet cafes in Texas. (Financial News <https://www.houstonchronicle.com/neighborhood/fort-bend/article/first-cup-coffee-pearland-19758155.php>)
The Indian tech center trade is by no means at an end – Julius Baer, Sumitomo Mitsubishi and Vanguard are all setting up new global capability centres, and hiring as many as 1,000 workers between them. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-17/smbc-julius-baer-among-firms-setting-up-india-tech-centers>)
A blow to the image of the Abu Dhabi global financial centre, as their flagship annual conference suffered a cybersecurity failure which leaked the passports and identity documents of attendees including Alan Howard, Anthony Scaramucci and the CEO of Binance. (FT <https://www.ft.com/content/b86cefd5-90e7-410b-bf58-09b9fde307cb>)
Prediction “markets” are currently regulated by the CFTC in the USA, but they’re coming under increasing pressure from state gambling regulators who think that the majority of “traders” don’t seem to “invest” in any “contracts” that aren’t to do with sports events. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-17/cftc-faces-more-pushback-from-states-over-prediction-markets?srnd=homepage-uk>)
McKinsey has launched “tens of thousands” of AI agents, and is currently engaged in a project to find out whether they are adding value in terms of allowing the consultants to generate more revenue. Unfortunately, the usual management consultancy research techniques cannot be used in this case, as the rest of the industry doesn’t know either, and you can’t find the right person to ask at the client. (Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/mckinsey-bcg-pwc-ey-ai-agents-adoption-value-consulting-industry-2026-2>)
Jeffery Epstein claimed to “hate” the World Economic Forum, and it’s not clear whether he ever actually went there, but this didn’t stop him claiming to be a “Davos concierge” and trying to put together meetings between people who would presumably now rather forget about them. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-17/jeffrey-epstein-davos-emails-reveal-his-use-of-wef-to-broker-elite-meetings?srnd=homepage-uk>)
The acquisition of Schroders by Nuveen means that the name “Cazenove Capital” may have a new owner. This once-storied local champion now only lives on as part of the branding of JP Morgan’s London operation, but it might be worth something to a sentimental bidder. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2026-02-17/is-cazenove-still-a-city-of-london-name-to-be-proud-of?srnd=homepage-uk&embedded-checkout=true>)
Some banker somewhere has almost certainly done this. Marx Arriaga, the Mexican government official responsible for producing school textbooks, has refused to accept his dismissal and keeps coming to the office. (FT <https://www.ft.com/content/b4808fbf-3125-4133-8bad-5a889d248480>)
The bankers’ commuter paradise of Potter’s Bar is now the scene of a planning battle over a massive datacentre. (WIRED <https://www.wired.com/story/the-small-english-town-swept-up-in-the-global-ai-arms-race/>)

item.title: ExodusPoint's lessons for Jain Global: Multistrategy hedge funds mature with time
item.description:
It wasn't so long ago that ExodusPoint, the fund founded in 2018 by Michael Gelband, was the limping dog of the multistrategy hedge fund </news/big-multistrategy-hedge-funds> world. Times, however, have changed.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Last year, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-02/bridgewater-d-e-shaw-among-biggest-hedge-fund-gainers-in-2025>reported that ExodusPoint generated returns of 18.4%. In so doing, ExodusPoint outperformed both Citadel's Wellington Fund (10.2%) and Millennium (10.5%), where Gelband was previously head of the fixed income division. It also generated returns five times higher than the 3.7% reportedly <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-15/jain-hedge-fund-costs-cut-into-750-million-profits-last-year> generated by Jain Global, </news/jain-global> the fund founded by Bobby Jain, Gelband's former colleague and Millennium's ex-co-chief investment officer.
As Jain Global battles redemption requests <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-13/singapore-s-gic-pulls-250-million-from-hedge-fund-jain-global> and Substack posts <https://rupakghose.substack.com/p/jain-global-getting-past-the-j-curve?utm_source=substack&publication_id=1898843&post_id=188036666&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share&triggerShare=true&isFreemail=true&r=qrn8&triedRedirect=true> questioning the wisdom of its 50 different pods, Gelband's ExodusPoint is a reminder that multistrategy hedge funds can take time to get going.
Similarities between Jain and ExodusPoint extend beyond their founders' time at Millennium. Both firms were initially celebrated as major hedge fund launches: ExodusPoint launched with $8bn, Jain with $5.3bn. Both seemed to falter. During its first half year of operation, ExodusPoint generated returns of 0.57%, only slightly higher than Jain's 0.5%. In 2022, ExodusPoint suffered $400m+ of redemptions, followed by another $1bn </news/exoduspoint-hedge-fund-hiring> in the first half of 2024. But now look.
ExodusPoint's redemptive arc is also a reminder, however, that the going is not always smooth. The fund cut 25% of its portfolio managers in late 2022. going from 108 to 81 people. It's resisted big hiring ever since. Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/exoduspoint-hedge-fund-performance-success-gelband-2025-7> reported last June that ExodusPoint had held its headcount steady at 650 people after slimming down from 688 people in 2022. While multistrategy hedge funds as a whole increased headcount by 64% over that period according to Goldman Sachs </news/multistrategy-hedge-fund-jobs>, ExodusPoint sat on the sidelines.
Does this mean that Jain Global will also need to cull some of its 400 employees to thrive? Not necessarily. Jain and ExodusPoint come with important differences. ExodusPoint, for example, told Business Insider that 75% of its risk is invested in fixed income funds, and that this has helped juice its returns in recent years. By comparison, Jain Global has set out to build a more diversified business covering all asset classes, including commodities. This should leave it better placed to ride out varying market conditions.
Jain Global has also invested heavily in the sort of centralized and scalable infrastructure platform that contributes to high costs in the short term but that pays off when assets under management (AUM) grow. All that's needed is a bit of momentum. As Jain gets out of toddler phase, this is what it needs most of all in 2026.

item.title: How to get a compliance job in banking and financial services
item.description:
Compliance professionals are the like the police of the banking industry. They exist to make sure that banks follow the regulatory rulebooks. Compliance jobs can be stressful, but the compliance profession has risen in importance and prestige since the financial crisis. Law can be a starting point for a job in compliance, but banks run training programs too.
In financial services, the compliance function serves two key purposes. Firstly, it ensures that the institution operates within all applicable laws, rules, regulations, and standards. Secondly, it creates and maintains a “compliance culture”.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The compliance team ensures that an institution operates within the rules and regulations applicable to its specific lines of business. You could say that compliance operates as an internal police force, monitoring behavior and tracking adherence to specific rules and regulations.
Laws are typically created by government bodies and administered and enforced by government agencies. These agencies create rules that firms must obey. The interpretation of these rules requires both a thorough understanding of the law and an appreciation of the practicalities of the businesses affected. The compliance function provides this interpretation.
Compliance is also responsible for the establishment and maintenance of an appropriate compliance culture within a firm. That involves not only line-by-line review of the rules and regulation, but also the education process – as well as the creation, along with senior management and the Board of Directors, of a compliance program for the entire company. This notion of a “compliance culture” goes well beyond employee training. It’s about influencing behavior and setting expectations so that adherence to rules and regulations becomes second nature.
The importance and influence of the compliance function within financial institutions has grown dramatically since the Great Financial Crisis of 2008. While compliance has always been important, the explosive growth of regulation as a result of the weaknesses exposed by the crisis has brought compliance needs into sharp focus.
Jobs available in financial compliance
There are a number of jobs available in compliance.
Know Your Customer (KYC): KYC due diligence is conducted for both new and existing clients and investors. It’s an ongoing process, as the origins of investors’ funds can change over short periods of time. There are two key objectives to each due diligence exercise: a) the identification and verification of investor’s identity and b) determining the ultimate purpose of the investment.
Anti-money laundering (AML): AML programs are a key to compliance. AML staff review the details about new and existing clients in terms of their locations, their relationships with others, and the laws applicable to them. The key elements of AML include training staff to spot money laundering issues, client due diligence, the designation of an AML officer, independent testing, and governance documentation (policies and procedures).
Compliance Risk Management: Financial institutions of all kinds require governance processes to be carried out and monitored to reduce the risk that regulations are infringed. Compliance risk managers look at everything from the compliance reporting to roles and responsibilities within the compliance function, the disclosure of information about transactions, insider trading prevention, secrecy and privacy, recordkeeping of transactions and complaints, and potential conflicts of interest.
Business Conduct: These jobs are about embedding a firm’s culture of compliance and code of ethics into specific business practices. Adherence to the specified requirements is constantly reviewed.
Compliance monitoring, documentation, and reporting: Information flow is a key part of the compliance process. If you work in monitoring, documentation, and onboarding, your job will involve keeping an eye on how clients are being onboarded, on transaction flow and on policies and procedures to maintain an effective control environment. Technology has made these roles much easier: compliance monitoring professionals now have easy access to data about trades, clients, conflicts, and market practice. Their role is to aggregate, report, and interpret this data. They also manage the information flow to the board of directors and senior managers, ensuring that they’re fully aware of the compliance risk profile at the heart of the bank.
Career paths in compliance
There’s no specified background for a career in compliance, but it’s also not uncommon for people with a background in law, business, accounting, or finance to move into compliance jobs. If you have a legal background, for example, you might find it possible to immediately apply your knowledge of relevant securities laws and regulations.
If you’re not coming from a legal position and are looking for an entry-level compliance job, you might find that you start out in the “control room”. The control room is responsible for the maintenance of the information “wall” between the public side of the institution dealing directly with investors and the private side which has access to non-public, confidential information.
Other entry-level compliance jobs include screening clients for criminal activity (KYC), ensuring that anti-fraud checks are carried out; performing due diligence on payments to make sure funds aren’t being used to finance illicit activities (AML); or providing information to regulators and law enforcement agencies. Ultimately, these functions are all managed by senior compliance managers, but there are plenty of junior opportunities too. The nature of your job in compliance will depend partly on the kind of firm you work for. For example, in a small institution like a startup hedge fund, a compliance officer could wear several hats including customer and payment screening, managing people and writing policies. If you have a compliance job in a big bank, your work is likely to be much more specialized.
Ken Weiller, a veteran compliance and operating professional with experience in both banks and the hedge fund industry says compliance professionals in hedge funds have become more prominent in recent years. “The compliance staff interacts regularly with the rest of the firm on multiple levels; by setting policies and being the point person for their implementations,” says Weiller. He says that compliance professionals in hedge funds have responsibilities spanning everything from approving and regulating employees’ personal trades to participating in decisions about the allocation of expenses to investors.
At many firms, compliance personnel are involved in daily trading/research meetings as well as being members of firmwide committees dealing with areas such as valuations and conflicts of Interest,” Weiller adds.
What skills do I need for a career in compliance?
If you want a job in compliance, it will help if you have the following skills.
Legal and regulatory skills: More than anything else, you’ll need an understanding of the legal and regulatory framework surrounding both the business you cover and the overall financial services industry. The regulatory environment is constantly changing. You’ll also need to be acutely aware of the changes and the implications for the way business is done. Failure to do so may have severe financial and reputational costs.
Communication skills: Good compliance people have excellent communication skills. While this requirement is not unique to compliance, it is particularly important given that a major component of the job involves the explanation of often-complex rules and regulations. Compliance is often called to provide interpretations of complicated rules that must be understood by everyone from new hires to senior management.
Problem solving and critical thinking skills: You’ll need to be a good problem-solver. The rules are not static. Compliance officers are charged both with addressing current issues and anticipating potential new ones. They must have a good sense for the direction of business practice and the evolution of the laws and regulations.
People skills: Compliance issues affect everyone in an organization and staff must be able to establish good relationships from the top to the bottom. This requires an ability to “read” individuals and to develop relationships that span the organization. This can be tricky; compliance sometimes has to say “no.”
Business acumen: Compliance people need to understand the functions they cover. They must be seen as promoting the interests of their internal clients and not labelled as the “business prevention department.” Being called “commercial” is one of the highest compliments a compliance officer can receive.
Technical knowledge: Technology is changing rapidly in financial services. Compliance professionals need to understand technology infrastructure. The rise of crowdfunding, use of cryptocurrency, growth of digital banking, and increased reliance on cloud storage mean that today’s compliance professionals increasingly need technical expertise. Compliance is increasingly about the way that data is collected, aggregated, processed, and stored.
Personal integrity: Compliance officers are often called upon to make difficult decisions. They need a keen sense of right and wrong. Banks rely on compliance to define the often-vague restrictions written into laws. Compliance professionals need to be “above the fray”, and capable of making the right call even when it may be unpopular.
Education & qualifications for financial compliance jobs
Compliance holds a unique place in the banking recruitment ecosystem because it does not usually recruit finance graduates.
When we took a glance at JPMorgan’s junior compliance personnel, for instance, we saw that a significant number studied law in some capacity (although not all). That’s a natural byproduct of a less numerically focused profession than other roles in an investment bank.
There are a number of additional qualifications that can be done in pursuit of your compliance career, too. In the UK, there’s the CISI Diploma in Investment Compliance There’s also the International Compliance Association’s (ICA) Compliance certificate, which is also UK-focused, although not as widely recognized as CISI’s. The American Bankers Association also offers qualifications in the U.S., as does the Independent Community Bankers Association (if you want to work for a community bank).
Specialization further into your career is also possible. In private banking, for example, there’s the Certified Anti-Money Laundering Specialist (CAMS), issued by the US-based Association of Certified Anti-Money-Laundering Specialists.
Salaries and bonuses in compliance
Compensation in risk roles are not as good as they are in front-office roles such as investment banking and sales & trading, but they’re still healthy.
Our 2025 Salary and Bonus report showed that salaries for compliance & risk management professionals, which we aggregated, ranged between $43k for juniors to $600k for managing directors (MDs).
Although pay increases at a similar rate to front-office roles (albeit from a lower base), the main distinguishing factor for middle-office roles (like compliance and risk roles) was much lower bonuses. Only around 10% of total compensation for associates was in a bonus, 12% for VPs, and 28% for directors.
