item.title: Hedge fund Balyasny hired Bank of America's head of FICC technology
item.description:
Bank of America' </news/bank-of-america-bonuses-are-out-they-may-be-moderately-good>s fixed income, commodities and currencies (FICC) division had a respectable 7.9% rise </news/bank-of-america-s-credit-trading-turnaround-slow-to-start-after-leadership-changes> in revenues last year. Despite this, and despite adding markets technology staff <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/bank-of-america-revamps-trading-tech-as-it-eyes-top-three-spot-in-europe-12384dda> over the past year, one of the bank's most senior engineers has now left for a hedge fund.
Dhairyasheel Deshmukh, global head of FICC technology, has joined Balyasny. His role there is head of investment technology, reporting to CTO Mike Grimaldi. Deshmukh's LinkedIn suggests he'll be running front-office teams for all its divisions bar systematic: equities, multi-asset arbitrage, commodities and fixed income & macro. Deshmukh joined BofA in 2010 as an MD working on its risk management platform Quartz </news/2017/03/secdb-quartz-athena-analytics>.
Balyasny's equities division is its largest, employing 60+ PMs </news/where-do-portfolio-managers-work-balyasny#:~:text=As%20of%20May%201st%202025%2C%2044%25%20of%20its%20total%20investment%20headcount%20were%20in%20its%20equities%20business%2C%20led%20by%20Dmitry%20Balyasny%20himself.>including Dmitry Balyasny himself. Deshmukh's appointment is a little unusual, then, as he didn't appear to work on equities technology while at BofA. He was briefly co-head of global markets technology architecture, which may have included work on equities. Prior to joining the bank, however, he was an executive director and global head of equities algorithmic trading technology at JPMorgan.
Balyasny is looking to build on a good year, after it made 16.7% returns in 2025. It performed better than the likes of Two Sigma and Schonfeld, but was beaten by Qube, D.E. Shaw and others.

item.title: UBS's star London trader may be familiar with these bidding wars
item.description:
Where is Jonas Klink? Still on UBS's London rates trading desk. Maybe not for much longer, though: it seems that all sorts of places would like to hire him.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Neither Klink nor UBS commented for this article, but as we noted in today's Morning Coffee </news/goldman-sachs-board>, International Financing Review <https://www.ifre.com/people-and-markets/2384579/ubs-bags-hefty-trading-gain-in-europes-sleepiest-bond-markets> (IFR) is claiming that Klink and his small trading team doubled UBS's revenues from SSA and covered bond trading, to $80m last year. As a result of this, Klink himself is said to have become a hedge fund hiring target and the potential subject for a bidding war.
Unfortunately it's now too late for UBS to allocate a higher bonus </news/ubs-markets-bonuses> to Klink for his efforts in 2025, but it may want to consider paying him more for next year. Klink is already thought to be well paid. Almost exactly two years ago, we reported that he was allegedly the subject of another bidding war </news/2023/02/jonas-klink-ubs>when he joined UBS from Citi, with Citi counter-offering </news/finance/counter-offer-banking> him and UBS upping its own offer to as much as $2m.
It's possible that Klink's initial package has now expired. IFR says hedge funds are now prowling Klink as they build their own covered bond and SSA desks.
This may be overstated, though. Although Global Capital <https://www.buzzsprout.com/1811593/episodes/18518933-fast-money-slows-down-to-take-on-ssa-bonds>reported last month that hedge funds now account for up to 15% of bids for sovereign supranational and agency (SSA) and said funds are setting up their own SSA teams, sources in the market say many funds are simply making do with the people they already have. "It's most people with broader backgrounds who are dipping their toes into covered bond and SSA trading in hedge funds," says one insider.
There are exceptions. As we reported last year, Point72 hired Bobby Previti </news/bank-of-america-s-ex-head-of-ssa-trading-is-building-a-pod-at-point72>, the ex-head of covered bond and SSA trading at Bank of America to build a pod in London. Huw Roberts, another ex-banking senior SSA trader is now sitting at Tudor in the UAE. And ex-Deutsche Bank and Nomura trader Jordan Griffiths was at Qube, </news/qrt-hedge-fund> but is thought to be enroute to Balynasy </news/2023/10/balyasny-hedge-fund> and on a non-compete, </news/killing-non-competes-will-make-hedge-fund-managers-more-boring-people> although this has not been confirmed.
It's possible that these funds might try to hire Klink. If they do, UBS might feel inclined to bid him back again. Both the bank and Klink should know the script.

item.title: Coinbase is hiring and paying an average of $374k despite its huge loss
item.description:
2025 wasn't the best year for Coinbase </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-coinbase>, mostly because it wasn't a good year for crypto </news/why-i-will-never-work-in-crypto-ever-again>. The exchange made a $667m loss <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-12/coinbase-posts-667-million-loss-sees-revenue-tumble-20> last year, down from a $1.3bn profit in 2024. This didn't stop it from hiring.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
A 10-K form filed with the SEC last week by Coinbase said that the firm had 4,951 employees at the end of 2025, up from 3,772 at the end of 2024. As a result, Coinbase ended 2025 with its highest headcount since Q2 of 2022, just before it cut ~20% of staff. Coinbase was busiest with recruitment in in Q3 last year, when it hired 500 people. During that quarter, Bitcoin crashed, with more than $19bn in crypto leverage <https://www.fticonsulting.com/insights/articles/crypto-crash-october-2025-leverage-met-liquidity> being liquidated on a single day in October. The following quarter, Coinbase was more measured, hiring only ~150 people. This was apparently a blip; Coinbase said in its shareholder letter that it expects headcount "to grow at a slightly higher rate than Q4."
Today, Coinbase has over 260 job openings, slightly down from the ~300 it had at the start of 2025. </news/coinbase-remote-jobs-pay#:~:text=Today%2C%20the%20fintech%20has%20303%20openings%2C%20of%20which%2080.9%25%20are%20remote%20positions.%C2%A0> Desired recruits are predominantly in engineering, with backend jobs being most common.
As new faces proliferate, average pay at Coinbase has fallen. Average 'employee-related expenses' per head (including cash and stock compensation </news/joining-a-fintech-startup-for-the-stock-pay-is-a-dead-end>), fell from $477k in 2024 to $374k in 2025. Expenses were generally flat in its technology and development division, down in marketing, and up in its general/administrative arm.
In Coinbase's shareholder letter, the fintech said that most of the recent hires were "added in our customer support and product teams;" the fall in average pay suggests more of the former have been hired than the latter.
Nonetheless, Coinbase made some big hires, even after the Bitcoin crash. Liz Martin, a partner at Goldman Sachs, joined Coinbase in November <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/coinbase-hires-ex-goldman-sachs-partner-liz-martin-to-lead-global-expansion-f97ee17a> as its head of product for derivatives and markets. Earlier in the year, Naveen Balraj, formerly of hedge fund </news/hedge-fund-weekend-working-four-day-week> Citadel and HFT firm </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> Flow Traders, joined as a product manager when Coinbase acquired options marketplace Deribit for $2.9bn in August. <https://www.theblock.co/post/366957/coinbase-completes-2-9-billion-cash-and-stock-acquisition-of-deribit>
Despite markets slumping, banks are still showing interest in crypto. UBS promoted Saurav Banerjee, head of digital asset compliance, to MD this year. Morgan Stanley has been seen hiring engineers focused on blockchain and tokenization this year on salaries of up to $165k. Citi is hiring a CIO of digital assets in its wealth arm, although the listing was supposed to close in October 2025, suggesting that banks are struggling to hire.

item.title: Citi also employed ex-JPMorgan banker's Ina De's sister as an MD until not so long ago
item.description:
As we reported yesterday, </news/the-big-question-at-citi-now-will-ina-de-arrive-soon-from-jp-morgan> the London market is chattering about the possible intentions of Ina De, the former vice chair of investment banking at JPMorgan. Has she genuinely retired? Will De join Citi? Is Vis Raghavan </news/citi-vis-raghavan> contemplating offering her a job alongside the other people he's hired from JPMorgan? </news/citi-s-newest-ex-jp-morgan-in-md-in-london-will-be-everyone-s-best-friend>
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
If De does join Citi, insiders at the bank are pointing out that she could ask for advice on navigating her way around from a family member. Citi formerly employed her sister.
Anita De was Citi's head of emerging markets fixed income rates sales for EMEA for 23 years until April 2024. Anita was previously a director at JPMorgan in London between 1991 and 2001. Ina joined JPMorgan's London office in 1987.
It's a reminder that banks employ clusters of sisters as well as brothers. Citi sources say that Anita was a popular figure at the bank. However, she left nearly two years ago after Citi simplified its ranks. "She was very smart," says one colleague, professing sadness at her exit.

item.title: Defence investing jobs: the buyside firms that hire bankers, and generals
item.description:
It’s never really a good time to work in defence, but as far as getting funding for your defence startup goes, it’s hard to beat this year. DefenseNews reported <https://www.defensenews.com/industry/2026/01/20/defense-tech-startups-had-their-best-funding-year-ever-in-2025/> last month that the value of defence venture capital </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-venture-capital> (VC) reached a record $49bn, up from $27bn last year. But where exactly is that money coming from?
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
It’s complicated. Defence is a touchy industry. Edward Crawford, co-founder and co-CEO of Coltala Holdings LLC, told S&P Global in March last year <https://www.spglobal.com/market-intelligence/en/news-insights/articles/2025/3/pe-defense-investment-surges-in-early-2025-as-geopolitics-drives-change-88086420?utm_source=chatgpt.com> that "if you're entirely defence, you're going to have to ride through some cycles, and that can be difficult for you.”
Private equity firms are a bit touchy about that, and overwhelmingly prefer dual-use firms, which have both civilian and defensive purposes. S&P Global noted that consulting firm Bain & Co. said in a note 2024 that “there are relatively few examples of scale private equity investments that primarily serve defense markets.”
VC firms, however, have fewer such qualms. And with around $200bn of the US military’s budget going to procurement of equipment, it’s a rich vein to strike. And with European defence budgets also reaching all-time highs <https://www.defensenews.com/global/europe/2025/09/02/eu-sets-military-spending-record-expects-more-growth-in-2025/>, it’s a profitable time to work in defence.
Here are the biggest (specialist) venture capital firms currently involved in defence.
AE Industrial Partners
With $7.5bn in assets under management (AuM) and 109 employees, Boca Raton-based AE Industrial Partners (AEI) is one of the biggest players in defense VC. The firm hires some pretty typical finance industry professionals - in December it picked up Brett Johnson, a VP from asset manager Exome that also spent two years at boutique investment bank Lazard. It also has a number of interns.
One of AEI’s most notable investments was in Gryphon Technologies, a “premier engineering and technical services provider” that has been working with the DoD in America for more than two decades.
Shield Capital
Shield Capital is one of the more military-heavy firms on the list. The San Francisco-based firm boasts US generals, secretaries of defence, and a NATO Supreme Allied Commander Europe on its advisory board. Its operating partner, Pat O’Reilly, who joined in June last year, was a Lieutenant General in the US Army. Many of its “regular” staff, such as Akhil Iyer and David Rothzeid, both principals at the firm, have extensive military experiences. Despite that, it still offers internships like a “normal” financial services firm.
Most of Shield Capital’s portfolio is small. Code Metal, for example, is an AI platform that translates code – from C++ or Rust or whatever else into “production-ready code” such as Python.
IQT
IQT is an interesting beast. It’s a not-for-profit firm based in Arlington with a budget of around $100m per year from Congress, and a mission to make sure the US’ intelligence agencies are always up to date with cutting edge technology. Despite the mission statement, it hires a lot of rather normal financiers, such as Connor Reese, a former Alvarez & Marsal consultant doing an MBA as a venture fellow in Arlington, Virginia. It also offers internships.
IQT has a history of impressive investments. It was an investor in both GitLab and Palantir, among 800 others.
Marque Ventures
Marque Ventures is pretty honest about what it is. Founded in 2022, the San Francisco-based firm has a relatively clear investment threshold: “a clear path to defense application”, and “emerging capabilities for use by the U.S. and allies”. A number of its investment staff are US veterans, such as Todd Coulard, a helicopter and drone pilot with over 16 years of experience who currently serves as a principal at the firm.
Some of Marque’s biggest investments include Mach Industries, an unmanned vehicle manufacturer developing something called the “Viper”, a "strike airctaft designed to redefine air combat."
Seraphim Capital
A pioneering space investor, London-based Seraphim Capital has around 145 investment credits and 5 IPOs to its name. Its staff has a wide variety in their backgrounds, with consultants, professors, journalists, and equity researchers all represented.
Seraphim Capital’s investments are deeply varied. One of the most interesting is the delightfully named Zeno Power, a power company producing, among other things, nuclear batteries for “reliable, clean energy from deep sea to deep space.”
Silent Ventures
Silent Ventures was started by Jackson Moses, a former Cisco market research analyst and rare whisky collector. He’s had a number of notable investments, including a Series A with space station manufacturer Axiom Space, as well as a full suite of Lord of the Rings inspired names: Erebor, Durin, and Anduril. Only Palantir is missing from his collection. It's based in Dallas.
Champion Hill Ventures
Champion Hill Ventures was founded by two marine corps veterans, Josh Manchester and Robert Haddick. Before starting Champion Hill, Manchester was a senior investment associate at VC firm TrueBridge, and before joining, Haddick was head of proprietary trading and research at the Fremont Group, the family office of the Bechtel family.
The firm has invested in a number of prominent space & defense companies including SpaceX, and was a First Round investor in Anduril, a $30bn defence tech firm. Champion Hill is based in North Carolina.
Marlinspike
Based in Washington DC, Marlinspike is a dual-focus VC firm focused on artificial intelligence, aerospace, robotics, and cybersecurity. It’s one of the more normal firms on the list – it hires interns, for example – but it also boasts the military credits of its leadership – VP Nick Snoad, for example, who spent four years as a consultant before joining the firm, and five years in the US army as an operations manager before that.
Marlinspike has invested in a number of defense darlings, including engineer manufacturer Volund Manufacturing and telescope manufacturer Observable Space.
Lockheed Martin Ventures
Lockheed Martin Ventures is a unique part of this list. For one, as the name suggests, it is a subsidiary of the aerospace giant. It only manages around $400m in AuM in an evergreen fund that started in 2007. It’s primarily staffed by regular finance people, such as Sam Stonberg, a senior investment manager at the firm who was previously in JPMorgan’s diversified industrials team.
It’s invested in a number of companies, which understandably haven’t outshone the Lockheed Martin brand themselves. An example is Agile Space Industries, an engineering firm focused on developing in-space propulsion systems using 3D printing.
RTX Ventures
Much like Lockheed Martin Ventures, RTX Ventures is the VC arm of RTX, formerly known as Raytheon. It employs pretty typical financiers – for example, Will Yeats, an associate director within the team that started his career in Wells Fargo’s investment banking team before moving to Booz Allen Hamilton, a cybersecurity consultancy.
Some of BTX Ventures’ investments include Ursa Major technologies, a rocket engine manufacturer.
Others
With defense having such a lucrative and reliable market when mature, it’s far beyond the domain of just boutique firms (or the internal operations of a few military-industrial giants). Noted firms such as Andreessen Horowitz and, with $90bn and $35bn in AuM respectively, have significant defense investment teams.
Andreessen Horowitz’s spectacularly named American Dynamism team, which was founded by Katherine Boyle and David Ulevitch, is a good example, having invested in now-established defense contractors such as Anduril and Apex Space.

item.title: Morning Coffee: Goldman Sachs might like more people like Tom Montag for its board. Teenage summers destroyed by dreams of banking jobs
item.description:
When Goldman Sachs summoned Tom Montag </news/2023/06/tom-montag-goldman-sachs> to join its board of directors in 2023, it was something of a homecoming. Montag, who spent over two decades at Goldman Sachs before leaving for Bank of America in 2007, knew Goldman Sachs. He knew David Solomon. He knew about banking and markets. Montag is now perched atop the Goldman Sachs risk committee, where uses his knowing to help steer the firm out of trouble.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Not all members of Goldman's board are Montags, though. One (Kevin Johnson, used to run Starbucks.) Another (Jan Tighe) was a vice admiral in the US navy. Ellen Kullman is a former CEO of manufacturing firm DuPont.
It's good to have a mix of perspectives on a board, even though Johnson's experience paying baristas may not be directly relevant when he's considering how to pay people at Goldman as part of the firm's compensation committee. But if there were a few more Montags, it might be good. And Montags are not always easy to find - especially if you're committed to finding diverse people to fill the seats.
Fortunately, then, Goldman Sachs is doing away with the diversity criteria that might stop it stocking the board with retired bankers or consultants. The Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/goldman-sachs-board-dei-57fea527?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqcXMPa6eo4ZEP9rBIZIW9Hjsz_BHSt9DXT2DtZ_iOvOKSdY8XUUod2D_TndoR8%3D&gaa_ts=6994248c&gaa_sig=x9rwAQNppW6Tv07222eL_U4F4XjTvH9ahfO3RqxlgPRRvg-uwgZzIAhHCRkD17nlIJXkByd0EgfFhuCE3EqXsA%3D%3D>reports that Goldman plans to scrap the DEI criteria that have committed it to considering 'race, gender identity, sexual orientation and other diversity factors' when making board appointments. Henceforth it will be meritocracy straight down the line.
The composition of the Goldman Sachs board in 2007 suggests the likely outcome of this change. During the glory days in the foothills financial crisis, Goldman's board comprised 10 men and two women, instead of the nine men and five women it has now. One of the men from 2007 had a gateau-related background as the ex-chief executive of Sara Lee, but most of the others had worked in financial services or consulting. As Goldman's DEI requirements are rolled back, the firm's board may become the ultimate resting place for the big (male) beasts of finance once they've done their time elsewhere. That may, or may not, be a good thing.
Separately, young people are also becoming less diverse as they find themselves corralled into pursuing careers at ever-younger ages. The Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/us-news/education/college-admissions-summer-resume-activities-high-school-d2bfe312?mod=e2tw> reports that overachieving teenagers are working on 'summer portfolios' and crafting 'narratives' that will get them into top universities and then top jobs. Hanging-out aged 16 is no longer a thing. Spending time interning or signalling an intense interest in your chosen area is where its at. This might be what it takes to become a future Goldman Sachs board member.
Meanwhile...
Ex-Citi trader Jonas Klink is a new star on the UBS SSA and covered bond desk. Hedge funds really want to hire him, says someone. (IFR) <https://www.ifre.com/people-and-markets/2384579/ubs-bags-hefty-trading-gain-in-europes-sleepiest-bond-markets>
Morgan Stanley reshuffled its EMEA investment banking team. William Bertagna is the new head of investment banking for EMEA. Karsten Hofacker is taking up the role of head of EMEA financial sponsors M&A. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-16/morgan-stanley-names-bertagna-deputy-emea-investment-bank-head?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260216&utm_campaign=author_18657817>
Did Kathryn Ruemmler </news/kathy-ruemmler-goldman-sachs> leave Goldman Sachs because clients were complaining and refusing to participate in women's projects? (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/finance/how-kathy-ruemmler-and-goldman-sachs-finally-reached-their-breaking-point-4c33d77e?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqek2xJJXC5KihrGZtAOJz0XMIgwkdgRdyADshFVOPOboYyVQAC9gIIBOfcEo-c%3D&gaa_ts=69939529&gaa_sig=KZgOR549BFTe9tGXVUIrQLTWMPk0qdcME1PtIi0zmcvlHgvAtXGH5Vth2CRA5aNdOFebJNNJkdzbsLttmNvzeQ%3D%3D>
Citi is building a crypto wealth business. (X) <https://x.com/fintechfrank/status/2023431283288715321?s=20>
Here are 12 insane Claude prompts that replace $400K/year quant researchers. (X) <https://x.com/heynavtoor/status/2023309961762336863?s=20>
If you study at the Indian School of Business, your salary will increase 248% to $202k. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/414d2b8c-20d4-4892-a730-255c0af7edb8>
A partner at KPMG Australia was found out using AI tools to pass an AI exam. (FT) <https://scandals across multiple countries in recent years.>
The chief executive of NatWest says graduates hired into banks in the future will be scientists, software engineers, architecture planners and “prompt engineers.” (Telegraph) <https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2026/02/13/study-tech-if-you-want-to-work-in-banking-natwest-chief/>
Many women are no longer reading books about leaning-in, but are embracing rest and self-care. “Caring about your job is silly.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-16/why-burnout-feminism-is-replacing-the-girlboss-lean-in-era?taid=6992f40b8d6c4d0001347fdb&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>
When you leave banking, everyone expects you to work for free. This includes providing careers advice and helping friends with start-ups. There is a belief that "you don’t need the money anyway." (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/ad99be3e-aa2e-4de5-b6bc-8684058f1c30>
A side effect of Ozempic seems to be "extreme apathy". (Vox) <https://www.vox.com/explain-it-to-me/479202/glp-1-flatness-apathy-symptom?utm_campaign=dhtwitter&utm_content=%3Cmedia_url%3E&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter - >This is probably not good if you're a trader. (X) <https://x.com/auren/status/2023007813874696565?s=20>

item.title: What happens to top young traders in investment banks now? 33% join hedge funds
item.description:
2016 feels like a lifetime ago </news/2016/06/top-finance-jobs> and then some. We wrote about young traders climbing the ranks of banking in February </news/2016/02/young-traders-investment-banking> of that year. The list included trading </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank> prodigies that made managing director in their 20; many have since gone on to even bigger and better things.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
We've looked at what 15 of them have been up to since then and found wildly diverging paths. A third have gone to hedge funds </news/all-the-jobs-in-hedge-funds>, while. Only 4 stayed in banking, but half of those are at a new employer. Two are now at tech firms. Below is what each of them do now, and what they were up to as star traders in 2016.
Rani Nazim: Credit Portfolio Manager </news/finance/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund-lifestyle> at Verition
In 2016: Credit Trading MD at Morgan Stanley
Rani Nazim made MD aged 33 in what was a very bad year to be a Morgan Stanley credit trader. While 25% of the division was cut, she was promoted.
She stayed with the bank for eight years, helping to build out the leveraged finance, algorithmic trading </news/algorithmic-trading-work-life-balance> and portfolio trading businesses in Morgan Stanley's European credit trading team. She left in late 2023 to focus on being an angel investor with a sustainability/AI focus, but entered the hedge fund space with Verition just three months ago. </news/rani-nazim-morgan-stanley-verition>
Andrew Silverman: Head of Credit, Discretionary Macro & Fixed Income at Schonfeld
In 2016: Distressed Debt Trading MD at Goldman Sachs
Silverman, a Harvard </news/2023/04/elite-universities-finance> educated math genius, made MD at Goldman Sachs aged 28 in 2014.
Silverman bounced between a few firms before landing at Schonfeld. </news/hedge-fund-schonfeld-s-ceo-suggests-ai-will-mostly-eliminate-data-jobs> He first left for asset management firm GoldenTree where he was head of leveraged credit trading, then joined another investment firm, Anchorage Capital, as an MD. He was hired by Schonfeld in 2022 to set up its credit unit; he joined as the fund grew its headcount from 600 to 900 in just over a year. <https://www.businessinsider.com/schonfeld-strategic-advisors-launching-new-credit-unit-macro-trading-2022-10#:~:text=The%20firm%20now%20boasts%20close%20to%20900%20employees%2C%20up%20from%20600%20in%20mid%2D2021.>
Dan Avery: Delta One Portfolio Manager at Balyasny Asset Management
In 2016: Index Trading MD at Goldman Sachs
Avery was aged just 28 in 2016, when he became an MD at Goldman Sachs. He was the youngest in his class, but has really made his name over on the buy-side.
Avery left Goldman Sachs in 2020 to join hedge fund Millennium. In early 2024, he was made a partner at the fund, but that didn't stop him from leaving for Balyasny later that year. He was thought to run around $1bn at Millennium </news/dan-avery-balyasny#:~:text=It%27s%20understood%20that%20Avery%20ran%20around%20%241bn%20at%20Millennium%20and%20that%20his%20team%20will%20have%20a%20similar%20allocation%20of%20assets%20at%20BAM.> and reportedly ran a similar amount at the time he joined BAM.
Simon Drake: Convertibles Associate Investment Officer at Rokos Capital Management
In 2016: Convertibles Trading VP at JPMorgan
Simon Drake was a Forbes 30 under 30 nominee <https://www.forbes.com/profile/simon-drake/> in 2015. His profile described him as a "top corporate bond market maker, trading hundreds of millions of dollars in daily volume in investment grade corporate debt." He was also the first trader on the list to have never made MD at their respective bank.
Drake left JPMorgan in 2019, taking up portfolio manager roles across a few hedge funds including BlueFin Capital Management. Since 2024, he has worked at Rokos Capital Management, the hedge fund ran by ex-Goldman Sachs trader Chris Rokos.
Darren Dixon: Founder of Kingston Infrastructure Partners
In 2016: Structured Credit Trading MD at Goldman Sachs
Darren Dixon lived up to the hype at Goldman Sachs after he made MD in 2016. After six more years at the bank, he became Goldman's youngest black partner, but he left the bank just two years later. </news/2022/04/black-partner-leaves-goldman-sachs>
Today, he runs Kingston Infrastructure Partners, a Miami-based investment firm. Late last year <https://www.themiddlemarket.com/news-analysis/tallvine-raising-1-5b-for-debut-fund-as-infra-spinouts-gather-pace#:~:text=Kingston%20Capital%20Management,America%20and%20Europe.>, it was raising funds for its debut infrastructure fund, targeting $2bn.
Nila Das: Chief Operating Officer at Proof Trading
In 2016: Mortgage Trading VP at Citi
Nila Das, like Drake, was a well regarded trader that achieved a 30 under 30 nomination <https://www.forbes.com/profile/nila-das/> as a VP, but did not convert that momentum into an MD promotion.
Das was promoted to director in 2019 and spent another three years at the bank but ulimately left for Proof Trading, an equities execution platform spun out of the IEX exchange.
Rany Moubarak: Head of Global Markets for Middle East and Africa at Nomura
In 2016: APAC Head of Fixed Income Structuring at Morgan Stanley
Moubarak is something of a journeyman; he started his career with Morgan Stanley in London before moving to Dubai </news/hedge-fund-managers-leave-london-tax> then later Hong Kong, </news/best-university-for-banking-jobs-hong-kong-singapore> where he made MD. He joined Nomura in 2021, still in Hong Kong, as its co-head of global markets structuring for Asia, then moved back to Dubai for his current role.
Kunal Shah: Co-CEO of Goldman Sachs International
In 2016: Partner at Goldman Sachs
Probably the most recognizable name on the list, </news/2014/11/kunal-shah-goldman-sachs-md-30-partner-32> Kunal Shah was already living the dream as a 32-year-old Goldman Sachs partner. He was one of the youngest ever traders to make MD at Goldman, aged just 27.
Alongside running Goldman Sachs International, the bank's European arm, Shah also co-heads the bank's global fixed income, currencies and commodities division.
Sam Berberian: Head of Credit Trading at Citadel Securities
In 2016: High Yield Credit Trading MD at Goldman Sachs
Berberian just missed the cutoff for being a Goldman MD in his 20s, but he presumably won't be complaining. Since then, he has worked his way up to a senior role at one of the largest electronic market makers </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> in the world.
Berberian first left Goldman for Citi in 2018 to be its head of high-yield credit trading, then left for Citadel Securities </news/citadel-securities-vs-jane-street> five years later. The market maker was on track to pay $2m per head </news/citadel-securities-pay-2025> last year, but high performers presumably earned much more.
Philipp De Cassan: Portfolio Manager at Verition Fund Management
In 2016: Rates Trading MD at Nomura
De Cassan headed Nomura's linear rates trading team in 2016, aged 31. He left two years later for London hedge fund LMR partners and has moved between hedge funds since then. De Cassan spent two and a half years at LMR before a four-year stint at Point72. He joined Verition last year.
Jonathan Birnbaum: Founder of OpenYield
In 2016: Credit Trading VP at Morgan Stanley
Birnbaum is another 30 under 30 nominee <https://www.forbes.com/profile/jonathan-birnbaum/> who managed a team of 100+ people aged 29. Rather than try for MD, he has been in and out of the fintech </news/best-place-to-work-fintech> sector.
After a few ill-fated attempts at founding a fintech, Birnbaum joined hedge fund Bridgewater to work in execution. Just under two years later, he left for a more mature fintech, digibank SoFi, then joined financial planning fintech Domain Money as its COO.
In 2022, Birnbaum tried his hand at founding a fintech again, launching credit pricing platform OpenYield. It raised $7m in seed funding in late 2024. <https://fintech.global/2024/11/22/bond-trading-platform-openyield-secures-7m-in-funding/>
Lear Janiv: Partner at Goldman Sachs
In 2016: Managing Director at Goldman Sachs
Another young Goldman MD to live up to the hype, Janiv made partner at the bank in 2022, leading the bank's exotic derivatives team. In 2023, Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-03-22/goldman-moves-senior-executive-to-paris-to-help-build-eu-trading> reported that he was moved from London to Paris and named head of FICC and equities trading for its main EU unit.
Adam Richmond: Unknown
In 2016: US Credit Strategy MD at Morgan Stanley
Some trading stars eventually opt for the quiet life, it seems. Richmond was promoted to MD in 2016 and worked at the bank until 2019 according to FINRA's BrokerCheck tool. It's not clear what he has been up to since then; his only activity on social media is a series of reposts, most recently for the Israel ParaSport Centre.
Roland Jeurissen: Co-head of FX Options at Morgan Stanley
In 2016: FX Options Trader at Citi
Jeurissen ran one of the largest currency trading books at Citi in 2016, aged 32. He left for Morgan Stanley a year later and, three years after that, he was promoted to co-head of FX options <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-01-31/morgan-stanley-shakes-up-top-ranks-of-fx-unit-at-center-of-probe>alongside ex-Citadel trader Alex Silverman.
Jon Deane: CEO of Trovio
In 2016: Commodities Trading MD at JPMorgan
In 2016, Jon Deane was head of JPMorgan's APAC commodities trading business, based in Singapore. He has since moved back to Sydney, where he went to University, and runs asset manager Trovio, which focused on trading crypto at launch. There hasn't been much news out of the firm, apart from one of its chief investment officer, Vimal Gor, in 2024. <https://www.afr.com/technology/what-it-s-like-to-launch-a-40m-defi-crypto-fund-20210930-p58w3a>

item.title: Banking MDs on bonus disappointment: "No one is ever happy"
item.description:
If you've been told your bonus for 2025 </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank>and it was below the number you desired, then - hey - welcome to the club. When we asked people to share bonus expectations </news/bonus-expectations-by-bank>late last year, expected increases of 40% or above were the norm. Instead, the reality seems to have been an increase of circa 10%.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
People communicating the numbers say it's been an unedifying bonus round as a result.
"Most people on my team were up by a reasonable amount, but not one of them was positive about their bonus," complains a trading desk head at major bank in London. "People really love to moan," he adds. "They seem to benchmark themselves to the once in a generation superstar and to think they're owed the same amount."
Pay charts released by European banks (and by US banks' European arms) highlight the fact that while many people in banking are paid well, some are paid stratospherically. At Goldman Sachs in London, for example, a mysterious group of 13 people </news/goldman-sachs-pay-london>always seems to earn over $9.4m each. At Barclays last year, three people earned over $16m. <https://cms.efinancialcareers.com/cms/content-manager/collectionType/api::article.article/60355>
These are the outliers.
Somehow, expressing unhappiness with any lesser bonus has become the norm. "No one is ever happy," says one banking managing director (MD) at a US bank. "I would be surprised if you find anyone who tells you their bonus was good."
Dissatisfaction as the default stance can grind you down. As ex-Goldman Sachs equity derivatives MD-turned leadership coach Michael Sloyer wrote here </news/Goldman-Sachs-Bonus-Day>two years ago, the constant quest for a higher bonus suggests a fragile ego addicted to extrinsic valuation. Nothing will ever feel good enough.
Equally, though, failing to object to a subpar bonus can set you up for a repeat next year. "You don't want to become known as someone whose bonus lands well regardless of its size," says the desk head. "You do need to complain when your bonus is average or poor."
The fundamental difficulty is therefore assessing whether your bonus was any good in the first place. This in turn depends upon choosing the correct comparators. "People often have somewhat skewed opinions about themselves. They compare apples to oranges," agrees Matthias Schwarz, the former head of EMEA credit trading at Bank of America, and founder of coaching firm Career Capital One.
The complexity of the problem explains why expressing dissatisfaction in all scenarios can seem optimal. If you've been underpaid, you won't seem happy with little; if you've been overpaid, you would happily have accepted even more. If you've been paid accurately, maybe you know something about your talents that they don't.
However, MDs say persistent ingratitude doesn't go unnoticed. "If you have a good bonus, say 'Thank you'," commands Schwarz. "If you complain when your bonus is good, it only makes you look stupid," confirms the desk head.
Complaining in a bonus meeting can, in any case, be ineffective. "It's like receiving a red card when you're playing football," says one MD. "You can scream and shout as much as you like but it won't change anything and you'll just seem annoying."
Schwarz says the best approach is instead to set up a follow-up meeting to converse about the, 'Why and the What.' - Why were you paid less than you'd expected for the last year and what can be done about it in the year to come. "It's futile to complain after the fact," says Schwarz. You need to focus on making amends before bonuses are announced in 2027.

item.title: The big question at Citi now: will Ina De join from JPMorgan?
item.description:
It's been nearly three weeks. Earlier this month, Bloomberg <https://news.bloomberglaw.com/mergers-and-acquisitions/jpmorgan-veteran-ina-de-to-retire-after-39-years-with-firm> reported that Ina De, JPMorgan's vice chair of investment banking was retiring. De had been with the US bank since 1987, so it's conceivable that her next move will entail a protracted period of lying down. Unless, of course, she joins Citi instead.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
As we noted nearly two years ago, </news/rumours-of-mass-resignations-on-jp-morgan-s-ecm-desk-may-be-premature> De was one of Vis Raghavan's close colleagues at JPMorgan. As Raghavan began assembling his new team at Citi, De was rumoured to be one of the many JPMorgan bankers </news/now-citi-hired-jp-morgan-s-former-global-co-head-of-sponsors-private-side-sales> he intended to poach.
Since that time, Citi has indeed hired various members of JPMorgan's ECM team, including Achtinya Mangla, </news/achintya-mangla-citi> Aloke Gupte </news/aloke-gupte-jpmorgan>, and Nicolas Skaff. </news/now-jp-morgan-s-head-of-private-markets-resigned-seemingly-for-citi>It's also hired an array </news/vis-raghavan-hire-from-jpmorgan-citi> of other bankers, including Guillermo Baygual, </news/guillermo-baygual>who arrived last October as the co-head of global M&A, based in London.
Citi declined to comment for this article and we haven't spoken to De. Technically, she still seems to be employed by JPMorgan - the FCA Register shows De still registered with the bank. However, Citi insiders are wondering whether De will ultimately turn up there. One observes that Baygual, who spent 25 years at JPMorgan, was also supposed to be retiring when he left the bank, but this turned out not to be so.
If De is joining Citi, it might be summer before she arrives. Mangla himself left JPMorgan to pursue other opportunities in </news/achintya-mangla>April 2024 and walked into Citi six months later. Six months is the standard period of gardening leave for senior people, so De would start at Citi in August.
While Citi is hiring from JPMorgan, JPMorgan has also been hiring from Citi. Last year, JPMorgan recruited Suneel Hargunani </news/jp-morgan-s-latest-big-citi-hire-might-be-joined-by-more-after-bonuses>, who was Citi's co-head of EMEA equity capital markets (ECM) between 2019 and 2025. Hargunani is now JPMorgan's head of EMEA syndicate. He was a popular figure at Citi and it's not inconceivable that former colleagues will join him.
Citi, meanwhile, has also recruited non-JPMorgan bankers, including Ed Sankey, the former head of global equity capital markets (ECM) at HSBC, who's now managing its business in EMEA. If De joins, she will be working with Ed.
Not every JPMorgan leaver joins Citi. Klaus Hessberger, who previously worked alongside De at JPMorgan as head of the strategic investors and financial sponsors business, joined Lazard in October. </news/gardening-leave-banking>

item.title: The quiet intensity of algorithmic trading jobs in finance
item.description:
When people think of intense jobs in finance, they tend to imagine the 120-hour weeks </news/my-husband-works-120-hour-weeks-in-banking-and-i-m-concerned-for-his-health> worked by investment bankers. Algorithmic trading </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> jobs slip under the radar in this regard, but can be just as exacting.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Andrew Courtney, formerly head of international ETF trading at Susquehanna International Group (SIG) </news/susquehanna-pay-uk-sig>, recently appeared on a podcast <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXDozNbr7Js> to discuss quant trading careers. He said that quant traders </news/quant-jobs-finance> typically spend "all day" looking at "multiple monitors covered with numbers, signals, flashing lights... your eyes are flittering across those screens trying to extract meaning and signal from those patterns." Courtney's experience isn't unique to SIG; at Jane Street </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-jane-street>, tools are optimized for individual traders to the point where UI elements can be as little as six pixels tall. </news/jane-street-s-traders-on-1-4m-have-fighter-pilot-eyes-high-pain-thresholds>
The role requires such focus and intensity that Courtney said he'd "never had a lunch break in [his] career." The trade-off is that traders generally work around the times that markets are open </news/best-lifestyle-finance>, but that doesn't mean the work is inherently safer than a banker working until 4am. Around the time that Bank of America associate Leo Lukenas </news/leo-lukenas> infamously died of heart complications </news/finance/overwork-bankers>, Adnan Deumic, an algorithmic trader at the bank, also sadly passed. While Lukenas was allegedly </news/bank-of-america-says-leo-lukenas-didn-t-work-120-hour-weeks>working 120-hour weeks in its investment bank, Deumic was working half that. The New York Post <https://nypost.com/2024/05/19/business/inside-wall-streets-brutal-work-culture/> reported at the time, however, that the work was incredibly intense and Deumic didn't have time to leave his desk for a coffee.
A career in quant finance can also have long-term (but not necessarily bad) psychological effects. Courtney said that "thinking in bets is [such] a part of the culture at SIG that I can't not do it." He said that, whenever faced with uncertainty, he will "think of everything as a bet... I kind of don't understand how you talk to normal people, and they don't do that."

item.title: Morning Coffee: Does Citadel pay an average of $1.2m to all who work there? British bank's dubious pay negotiation tactic
item.description:
Miami-based Citadel </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel>is not a British hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job>. As such, even though several of its UK entities release regular accounts disclosing their pay </news/pay-at-hedge-fund-citadel-in-london-500k-to-21mm>, it's never been known how much Citadel pays on a global basis. Until now.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-13/citadel-s-sticky-employee-pay-weighed-on-5-3-billion-in-gains> has seen documents released by Citadel for a recent bond offering; they imply that average compensation at the firm is in seven figures.
The documents show the fund spending $4.5bn on operating costs in 2025. Pay is not broken out for the full year, but in the first nine months Bloomberg says compensation accounted for around 84% of Citadel's operating costs. On this basis, the firm spent $3.8bn paying its people last year.
Citadel's recent bond documents also don't say how many people it employs. But last year's regulatory filings </news/big-multistrategy-hedge-funds>from the firm said it had 3,153 employees, of whom 39% were in "investment roles" like analysis and portfolio management. </news/2023/09/portfolio-manager-job-hedge-fund>
On this basis, Citadel the hedge fund seems to pay an average of $1.2m to all who work there. Sister company Citadel Securities (the market maker </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> and electronic trading firm </news/best-electronic-trading-for-to-work-for>), which was on track to pay each of its people $2m </news/citadel-securities-pay-2025> the last time we looked.
Neither Citadel nor Citadel Securities are operated on the basis of equal pay for all who grace their desks, however. $1.2m may be an average pay figure at the hedge fund, but it will be heavily skewed towards high performing investment staff. In the UK, for example, 184 employees at Citadel's administrative arm each earned $498k for 2024; </news/pay-at-hedge-fund-citadel-in-london-500k-to-21mm> 24 top employees at the investment arm each earned $21m.
Bloomberg observes that Citadel's costs increased as performance faltered. The bond documents show that operating costs at the firm globally rose by 4% last year, even as net investment gains fell by 14% (although Citadel still generated over 10% in net returns). Citadel charges investors for employees pay in the form of pass through fees. </news/hedge-fund-pass-throughs>In theory, pay should be lower when performance falls. In reality Bloomberg says multistrategy firms' different investing groups can keep overall pay costs high because even when one strategy underperforms others still need to be rewarded.
Citadel asks its employees to reinvest half their bonuses </news/hedge-fund-bonus> above an undisclosed threshold into its Wellington Fund. A Citadel spokesman told Bloomberg that this gives them an "incredibly strong alignment of interests to our performance since they participate on the same economic terms as our external capital partners.”
Separately, it's not unusual for employees of banks to hold bank accounts with their employers.
Lloyds Bank in the UK is a case in point. The Times <https://www.thetimes.com/business/companies-markets/article/lloyds-investigates-using-staff-bank-account-data-pay-talks-v7557f9b2>reports that Lloyds Bank decided to take advantage of employees' bank accounts when negotiating their pay.
The British bank reportedly looked at 'aggregated data' from the bank accounts of its junior workers and then compared their spending habits to the general public so that it could determine how much to pay them.
The revelation has upset some Lloyds employees, and there is talk of "sinister" behaviour. However, it seems to have worked in employee's favour: they received a pay rise of between 7% and 9% as a result.
Lloyds' CEO Charlie Nunn offered words reassurance. It had been “a legal use case of using aggregated data for a relevant business outcome,” he declared. That's all fine then.
Meanwhile...
Singapore’s GIC redeemed $250m from Jain Global. This happened after the person who made the Jain Global investment at GIC left for Blackstone. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-13/singapore-s-gic-pulls-250-million-from-hedge-fund-jain-global>
This is just under 5% of Jain Global’s AUM. Jain Global requires investors to give 90 days’ notice and then only 12.5% of their money can be withdrawn in each quarter. Assuming the notice just went in, this would mean the AUM impact will be slow. Millennium’s terms are even more onerous, and its full redemptions take over five years. (Rupak Ghose) <https://rupakghose.substack.com/p/jain-global-getting-past-the-j-curve?utm_source=substack&publication_id=1898843&post_id=188036666&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email->
Arthur Goossens, BNP Paribas' co-head of commodities trading, has gone to Schonfeld. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-13/schonfeld-hires-top-bnp-paribas-commodity-trader-arthur-goossens>
NatWest paid its average material risk taker a £219k bonus last year, and £185k salary. (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/natwest-ups-bonuses-for-top-staff-by-13-as-trading-unit-jumps-71e34e10?mod=homepage>
Deutsche Bank's private bank unit is hiring up to 50 relationship managers in its emerging markets private banking unit this year as it expands in the Middle East and Asia. (Reuters) <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/deutsche-banks-private-bank-eyes-hiring-push-emerging-markets-2026-02-13/>
"I talk to my friends who work in financial services. They say this is the brain they’ve always wanted to have at my side—in terms of the capability to do arbitrage, to create decks that used to take me six hours, it’s taking six minutes, and now I can actually do the thinking that I want to do." (Derek) <https://www.derekthompson.org/p/why-americas-ai-discourse-feels-so?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email>
Here are 12 Claude prompts that replace $150K/year investment banking work. (X) <https://x.com/heynavtoor/status/2022646952664641694?s=20>
The trouble with using an enterprise AI system: The AI can pass that information along to anybody else who does your job, or in some cases just do the job itself. Over time, you could become a lot less valuable to your employer—and a lot more replaceable. (WSJ) <https://www.wsj.com/lifestyle/careers/ai-knowledge-capture-employees-a69a0e1c?mod=hp_lead_pos4>
If student loan repayment thresholds in the UK hadn't been frozen, the highest tax rate would kick in at £70k. Instead, it's £52k. (The Times) <https://www.thetimes.com/article/a6602b01-6ec9-4dc1-9f6a-58e358ff1964?shareToken=7f741a68ce18b231f75654fb0f8c948d>
The trouble with taking your employer to court. “I usually indicate to clients who are thinking of suing — whoever they are — that the best day in your lawsuit is generally the day you file the lawsuit.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2026-02-12/white-men-learn-that-suing-for-discrimination-can-damage-your-career?accessToken=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9.eyJzb3VyY2UiOiJTdWJzY3JpYmVyR2lmdGVkQXJ0aWNsZSIsImlhdCI6MTc3MDkwMTQ5NiwiZXhwIjoxNzcxNTA2Mjk2LCJhcnRpY2xlSWQiOiJUQUNIQzhLR0lGUEcwMCIsImJjb25uZWN0SWQiOiIzRjZEOUFGODlEQjQ0ODVGQkIxQzg2MjJFQzQ0MUQ5RCJ9.S1aIQvGCoawjhSIe4Qe_bqoQOrh725_aWuF7Qv45yvw>

item.title: Banking bonuses are up by 10%. Unless you are the CEO
item.description:
As we reported earlier this week, if your bonus is up by 10% this year, </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank> you are doing ok. Unless, that is, you are the CEO in which case a 10% rise puts you at the bottom of the pack.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
As banks steadily disclose pay packets for their CEOs, it's becoming apparent - once again - that many chief executives received hikes far larger than those accorded to their employees.
The biggest increase in total compensation so far went to Ted Pick at Morgan Stanley, who got a 34% hike and was warmly praised <https://www.sec.gov/ix?doc=/Archives/edgar/data/0000895421/000095010326001967/dp240377_8k.htm> for increasing pre-tax profit at the bank by 25% last year. The smallest went to Jamie Dimon at JPMorgan, who received a 10% pay rise more aligned to his rank and file.
If you're CEO of a bank, it's not just about your annual salary and bonus, though. Dimon will be doing fine with his modest increase because he also has a $250m option grant <https://www.barrons.com/articles/jpmorgan-ceo-jamie-dimon-stock-option-grant-5ac1afbc?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqcfXURQ6YWU3visNX4E9ikDQfqHB7WNqLQBq4CUHbmugNfoCIjNhEtPQGn7JQE%3D&gaa_ts=698f5bac&gaa_sig=MtXdMJBguwOhWqF8vuHjDof7-fM6Cd4IiTTbOSKRVwgATEvGWU7oW-qhaOmxUrKxL9t0eIuU-7qISh2ZWbG4kA%3D%3D> awarded in 2021 which is coming due in July 2026. David Solomon has his extra $80m retention bonus </news/what-makes-david-solomon-and-john-waldron-so-special>which was issued in January 2025 and vests in 2030 (and which is already up 50% in line with Goldman stock). Jane Fraser at Citi was given a $25m retention bonus last October that vests in 2030.
CEOs are not normal people and are measured on different metrics. David Solomon </news/kathy-ruemmler-goldman-sachs>, for example, was rewarded </news/david-solomon-goldman-sachs-pay> partly for "strong momentum" on executing strategic priorities. This may sound nebulous, unless you have organisational metrics at your fingertips, plus people who can configure PowerPoint slides showcasing your achievements.
Most CEO bonuses are deferred for at least three years. Ted Pick, for example, has to wait until 2029 to get 75% of his.
The big increases are a source of disgruntlement nonetheless, particularly for people who were zeroed or received a sub-inflation salary rise. "We had a record breaking year and we got nothing more, but the CEO got a double digit pay increase," says one of these individuals. "You couldn't make it up."

item.title: Put your questions to the coach who can get you a job in electronic trading
item.description:
However hard it is to get a job at a top investment bank </news/goldman-sachs-internship-acceptance-rate>, getting a job at a top electronic trading </news/best-electronic-trading-for-to-work-for>firm is harder still. Citadel Securities </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel>, for example, has an acceptance rate of 0.5% or less. </news/hedge-funds-are-cool-again-for-graduates-big-tech-is-out>Official figures for rivals </news/difference-between-electronic-trading-firms>like Jane Street </news/how-to-get-a-job-at-jane-street>aren't available, but are unlikely to be much higher.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
How, then, do you increase your chances of landing one of these jobs, which can pay interns </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay>$6k a week? Ash Cross, a coach who specializes in quant careers, has some advice.
Cross is available until February 19th in the Bubble <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/t/ama-im-a-quant-career-coach-supporting-internship-job-search-mfe-admissions/5111>, our anonymous community, where she will be answering your questions on a daily basis. If you want to put a question to her, you'll need to register first.
We put some questions to Cross ahead of her AMA. This is what she said.
What's your background?
AC: "I have a long background in careers coaching and was the associate director of careers services for the Masters in Computational Finance at Carnegie Mellon University [one of the top courses in the world]. </news/top-masters-in-financial-engineering-courses> I also began coaching students on how to get into top Masters in Financial Engineering courses earlier this year."
What does a quant careers coach do?
AC: "First I help people to understand exactly what the roles are. People don't know about the different types of opportunities or all the different institutions and they just hop to whatever they think is optimal. For example, there's a big difference between the job of a quant researcher </news/what-is-a-quant-researcher-hedge-fund>, a quant developer, </news/quant-developer-jobs-in-banking>a trader, and a quant risk manager and people often just try to guess which is best for them.
I help them to make an informed decision and then to use projects to build up the kind of CV </news/2023/08/jane-street-intern-cv-advice>that will maximise their chances of success."
What kinds of projects are those?
AC: "I might ask someone I'm coaching to go and find a financial data set and to create some novel analysis, or to build a machine learning algorithm that can analyse a transcript. You need projects that show familiarity with the role you're applying to and that demonstrate an understanding of the technical knowledge involved. For example, you'll need to show that you can use Python if you want to work in quant research."
Is it necessary to study an MFE to get a job at these firms now?
AC: "It's not mandatory but I work with a lot of US students with a 4.0 score in their undergraduate degrees who don't have internships </news/high-frequency-trading-internship> close to May. Electronic trading is an incredibly competitive field and if you've studied an MFE you will at least learn the skills and do the projects that will help you get a foot in the door."
Does an MFE pretty guarantee that you'll get a job?
AC: "Weak candidates from MFE courses still won't get hired. When you enter an MFE course you need to be as ready as possible for recruitment. Ideally, you need to complete a minimum of two to three internships. It's a very tough market. A college careers service can only do so much."
What if you simply cannot get into these electronic trading firms?
AC: "There are other options. Walmart and logistics firms hire quant researchers and I've seen an uptick in energy companies hiring quant researchers and traders recently."

item.title: Clear Street's 350+ engineers may not be so rich after all
item.description:
Bad luck to all the engineers over at Clear Street who were already planning how to spend their windfalls. Earlier this month, the "cloud native infrastructure technology firm" filed for an IPO </news/after-brutal-job-cuts-clear-street-will-make-some-tech-people-very-rich> to raise $1.05bn. It's now postponed this after cutting the valuation by two thirds.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Clear Street didn't immediately respond to a request to comment, but Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-12/broker-clear-street-postpones-us-ipo-citing-market-conditions>reported earlier today that the IPO is resting rather than relegated to the bin and that the listing had gained "strong interest" from investors. A Clear Street spokesperson told Bloomberg it will be reconsidered in the future.
It's not clear how this will be received by Clear Street staff. They included 350+ engineers and around 500 other employees whom Clear Street's initial filing said are in danger of being poached by rivals. "Competition in the technology industry for qualified employees is intense and many of these employees hold extensive knowledge and experience in highly technical and complex areas spanning technology and capital markets, including the options, equities and futures trading and clearing industry," said the filing.
Clear Street's employees could still make money from an eventual IPO. As we reported earlier this month, the firm has issued millions of restricted stock units to employees at prices ranging between $2 and $7.4. The IPO initially targeted a valuation of $40-$44 a share, but this was cut to $26-$28 a share on Thursday, before it was shelved.
Clear Street hired an array of London markets professionals last year and fired them again five months later. </news/brutal-job-cuts-at-new-york-fintech-s-london-office-are-raising-eyebrows> They can be forgiven for experiencing schadenfreude at the recent turn of events. Some are suggesting that Clear Street should have chased institutional accounts more vigorously. "Institutions and hedge funds are a better client base," says one.
Clear Street's IPO prospectus says it is rebuilding "capital markets infrastructure" and that it works with "individuals, institutions, intermediaries, and corporates." In September 2025, Clear Street said it worked with 87 institutional clients, up from 48 in 2023, and that 100% of their revenues had been retained from the previous year.

item.title: Now Nomura's global head of rates and FX trading resigned
item.description:
Changes are afoot at Nomura. After various exits </news/kilian-frensch> in the London macro business, we understand that Hoe Lon Leng, the global head of FX flow and rate trading has resigned as of today. So too has Clement Florentin, head of equity structuring for EMEA and Asia ex-Japan, and head of QIS structuring for APAC.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Both men were working for Nomura in Singapore. Not any more. It's thought they're both going to rival banks.
Nomura didn't immediately respond to a request to comment.
Long Leng was promoted as co-head of the business for Asia ex-Japan last June. His colleague Andy Law remains. There is speculation that Leng might join a Chinese bank after he toured China </news/nomura-fx-s-boss-went-to-china-and-bankers-need-to-pay-attention>and wrote about fine life is there.
Florentin joined Nomura from Credit Suisse in 2023.
Nomura's macro team has lost many people in the past year, including Kilian Frensch </news/kilian-frensch>, Kunal Parekh </news/another-trader-left-nomura-s-leaky-rates-team-before-christmas>, Gian Ameri William Johnson, Quinn Borley and Ruchelle Beltia. Frensch recently landed at UBS, which needs to restock its desk after its own exits </news/ubs-markets-bonuses>, and there are fears that others will join him.
The departures of Long Leng and Florentin before Chinese New Year are awkward timing for the Japanese bank.
While US and European banks have announced </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank> and are announcing bonuses, Nomura doesn't pay until April. There may more exits after that.
Nomura declined to comment.
