item.title: Do you still need to be a junior banker to get hired by Blackstone?
item.description:
Private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity> has long been the career dream for many aspiring finance professionals, even in a tough market </news/private-equity-work-hours>, but getting into a top firm </news/best-place-to-work-private-equity> isn't easy. Historically, to work in private equity for a firm like Blackstone </news/what-its-like-to-work-at-blackstone>, many people got a job at one of the major investment banks </news/what-is-an-investment-bank>, then accepted a deferred offer to join Blackstone in their first year. Today, paths into private equity aren't as one-dimensional.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Speaking this week's LSE's Alternative Investments Conference, Saleh Panahi, a senior MD at Blackstone, said times have changed. Although banking "is probably still the most common route into private equity, it now sits alongside a wider range of entry paths."
Panahi himself started out in banking himself with boutique </news/boutique-investment-banks> firm Lazard </news/lazard-q4-2025> and "didn't know what private equity was" when he first joined the bank. He was convinced to join PE when he "noticed some of my more senior colleagues moving into it."
That was back in 2012. Since then, Blackstone has massively ramped up its internship </news/internship-investment-bank> and graduate </news/finance-grad-job-uk> program. Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/blackstone-summer-analysts-associates-interns-steve-schwarzman-advice-2025-6#:~:text=The%20firm%20now%20recruits%20from,just%20for%20landing%20the%20internship.> reported last June that the firm hired over 170 interns in 2025. Blackstone has been hiring students from universities for over 30 years and used to be very selective. In 2015, Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/blackstone-summer-analysts-associates-interns-steve-schwarzman-advice-2025-6#:~:text=The%20firm%20now%20recruits%20from,just%20for%20landing%20the%20internship.> said it was hiring from nine schools. In the past 10 years, Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/blackstone-summer-analysts-associates-interns-steve-schwarzman-advice-2025-6#:~:text=The%20firm%20now%20recruits%20from,just%20for%20landing%20the%20internship.> said it reportedly hired from 1,000.
The only problem with this route is that Blackstone's acceptance rate is incredibly low and getting lower; Business Insider <https://www.businessinsider.com/blackstone-analyst-class-entry-level-recruiting-2025-11>reported it accepted 0.4% of applicants in 2021 and 0.2% of applicants in 2025.
Blackstone has also ramped up its hiring into non-investment roles which don't need bankers. As Blackstone grows, Panahi said the firm needs "more specialised expertise, and that widens the funnel for the types of CVs that make it into private equity." For example, he said that teams of quants </news/quant-jobs-finance>analyzing Blackstone's portfolio companies have "really taken off for us over the last ten years... really helping the top of house spot megatrends before it turns into publicly available data." Blackstone's data scientists sit within its operating team led by Rodney Zemmel, a PhD biologist who spent just shy of three decades at consulting firm McKinsey before joining Blackstone last march.
The firm's data science </news/the-highest-paying-data-science-jobs-in-finance>team is led by an ex-Credit Suisse M&A banker, Matt Katz, but you don't need banking experience to join the data team. Recent hires include Tim Bush, a PhD </news/do-you-need-a-phd-for-a-quant-job-in-finance> physicist who joined as an MD from DefenceTech firm Palantir. </news/palantir-engineering-culture-2am> Recent associate-level hires have previously worked at hardware startup Arena and Starbucks (as a data scientist, not a barista). Working as a quant or data scientist in a bank is also a route in. The issue with joining in these kinds of non-investment roles is that you're less likely to get paid carried interest </news/what-is-carried-interest>, the key appeal of working in PE for many people.
Blackstone has been diversifying its talent pool, while investment banks have been looking to cut off the supply of banking analyst talent. JPMorgan told juniors last year </news/accepting-investment-bank-offer-internship> that it would fire anyone that it found taking a future-dated offer, and Goldman Sachs made its analyst swear </news/goldman-sachs-oath> they had not taken a private equity offer on a regular basis shortly after. This seemingly put a kibosh on PE hiring last year, but many big firms simply pushed their recruitment drive to this January.

item.title: Morning Coffee: If you can't get an M&A job now, you never will. Ex-Apollo CEO's $600k a month family spending habit
item.description:
If you couldn't find an M&A </news/get-a-job-in-ma>job last year, and now you can't find an M&A job this year, destiny may not be on your side. Last year, many M&A bankers were hired. This year, talk is rife of a once in a decade M&A extravaganza.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Speaking at this week's UBS Financial Services Conference, JPMorgan's co-CEO of the commercial and investment bank, Troy Rohrbaugh </news/jp-morgan-s-investment-bank-co-heads-have-wildly-different-amounts-of-stock>, said the bank hired 1,000 people in the front office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> last year and that around 333 of those were "senior bankers." This year, co-head of global banking Filippo Gori, has said that JPMorgan wants yet more bankers <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-16/jpmorgan-is-hiring-across-europe-with-investor-confidence-rising> in Europe, where it intends to be, "hiring in every country, pretty much across the region."
If JPMorgan isn't your cup of tea, there are alternatives. Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/amp/articles/european-bank-execs-point-to-dealmaking-growth-after-lacklustre-fees-51e35794>points out that UBS wants another 25 managing directors, to add to the 25 managing directors it hired last year, with a focus on the US market. Deutsche Bank is hiring another 60 bankers, too, and is also thinking of the US. Wells Fargo has it in mind </news/wells-fargo-md-hiring>to hire another 25-30 senior bankers. Only Barclays seems hesitant, saying it's made the "investments" and "got the talent" and now expects the revenues to flow.
With luck, they will flow bounteously. CEOs speaking at this week's conference were unspeakably optimistic about the possibilities for this year. "I think it can be really possibly one of the better years we've seen in a very long time in M&A or certainly in that top decile," declared Rohrbaugh. "In terms of the M&A market, I think this could be a top decile, top quartile, certainly, potentially top decile kind of M&A opportunity set," pondered David Solomon at Goldman Sachs.
The subtext to this enthusiasm is that private equity firms are getting desperate. They need to sell existing investments and they can't stop waiting for a good price. "They've got to return capital, whether they're selling stuff and they're going to the M&A market or they're getting stuff public, they've got to return more capital," also said Solomon. Private equity firms really need some "liquidity events" in 2025, agreed Rohrbaugh. At the same time, Rohrbaugh said "trade corridors" are shifting to, "Middle East to Asia, Middle East to Europe, Middle East to Latin America. Asia to Europe," and that this too is creating opportunities.
Hiring senior bankers is usually followed by hiring junior bankers. Experienced vice presidents are in vogue </news/vp-pay-banking>, but associates </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> may follow. The only danger is the kind of black swan event that has become a white swan in recent years. Rohrbaugh observed that he was equally optimistic at the start of 2025: "And then April 2 happened."
Separately, if you're struggling to pay the bills each month, spare a thought for Leon Black, the former CEO of Apollo Global Management, whose personal run rate is out of control.
The Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/inside-a-5-billion-fortune-one-familys-ledger-in-the-epstein-files-23455b75?mod=e2tw>observes that the Black family are big spenders. Documents released in the Epstein files suggest they spend $600k a month. In a two month period in 2015, they spent twice that, including $27k on dining out, $35k on clothing, $67k on alcohol and $48k for landscaping at their home in the Hamptons. Eleven years ago, they also had a $484m loan to repay.
Leon Black is no longer at Apollo, but he is not buying £10 wine. Black still owns 7% of Apollo and is worth an estimated $14bn. At the time of the information in the Epstein files he owned seven homes, 11 cars, a Gulfstream jet and a Benetti yacht.
Meanwhile...
Wells Fargo has been hiring senior bankers and says: "We've hired roughly 100 or so senior folks across the investment bank." (Business Insider) <https://www.businessinsider.com/wells-fargo-hiring-spree-investment-bankers-2026-2>
Ted Pick at Morgan Stanley earned $45m for last year. He earned $34m the year before. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-11/morgan-stanley-lifts-ceo-pick-s-pay-32-to-45-million-for-2025?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260211&utm_campaign=author_20461763>
Citadel says Daniel Shatz, the global head of credit at Marshall Wace, stole its secrets for a new team. Marshall Wace says he did not. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-11/citadel-says-shatz-stole-secrets-to-build-marshall-wace-team?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260211&utm_campaign=author_3487187>
Alastair Hall, senior managing director for Europe, and Chris Hogg, a director who led the firm’s digital infrastructure investments, have left Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System after it wrote off investments in Thames Water. (FT) <https://www.ft.com/content/bf423077-2904-4498-bcee-626441cbbd2a>
Goldman Sachs has 130 bankers, traders and private-credit staff in India and they're in a shiny new building in Mumbai’s Worli business district. It also has 8,000 people in its Indian tech hub. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-10/goldman-s-push-bears-fruit-in-india-s-crowded-wall-street-field>
Deutsche Bank settled with Michele Foresti, its former head of structured trading. He had argued that he was wrongly implicated in an audit report looking at the Monte dei Paschi accounting scandal. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-12/deutsche-bank-settles-with-ex-banker-in-monte-paschi-lawsuit?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260212&utm_campaign=author_23851719>
33 year-old finance bro Mark Moran is launching a bid for Senate in Virginia, running as a Democrat against incumbent Mark Warner. (Business Insider) <https://www.businessinsider.com/wall-street-memes-mark-moran-congress-reality-tv-litquidity-housing-2026-2>
The new flex is to own a pub. "On the face of it, [pubs] can look inexpensive but ultimately that’s because they make no money. But if they can be run by a wealthy owner who doesn’t need the income, then the business can be more viable.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/ede1382e-4844-425e-b34e-97d805e717aa>
Goldman Sachs' dinner budget is now $35, up from $30. You need to work past 8pm to get it. (Business Insider) <https://www.businessinsider.com/goldman-sachs-raises-dinner-allowance-investment-bank-2026-2>

item.title: Citadel's pitch to students: Advise Central Banks what to do next
item.description:
You don't have to work for the US or British central banks to present your opinions on monetary policy. Nor do you need an internship </news/hedge-funds-with-graduate-training-programmes> with US hedge fund Citadel to impress the head of its fixed income business. If you're a current university student, both things can be achieved simply by entering a single competition.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Following last year's inaugural 'Fixed income and macro Central Bank challenge', </news/citadel-wants-us-students-with-ideas-for-the-federal-reserve> which was open only to students in the US and Canada, Citadel is back with two similarly named challenges open to first and second year students in the US, Canada and Europe.
Winners of the challenges receive cash prizes. They will also get to interact with Edwin Lin, Citadel's head of fixed income and macro. Lin returned from his brief sabbatical last year. He will be an active participant in the competition, as will Angel Ubide, Citadel's head of economic research for his business area.
Select competition entrants will work in small teams to develop monetary recommendations, before defending their thinking and presenting to a panel. Last year's winning team included Esther Yu, a physics and maths student at the University of North Carolina who coincidentally also won a previous women's datathon organised by Citadel.
Writing on LinkedIn, Yu says her team used "VAR models, a DSGE [Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium] simulation, and a modified Taylor Rule to weigh inflation risks against complex supply-side shocks and evolving labor market dynamics." Another member of Yu's team is an intern on Citadel's fixed income and macro team this summer.
Entrants have until February 27th to enter the US competition and until March 6th to enter in the UK. Last year, Yu says over 1,500 people entered in the US; 40 were selected to participate. Citadel says it's keen to hear from people studying mathematics, economics, statistics, computer science, or other STEM related fields.
Would-be entrants might want to familiarize themselves with the opinions of Ubide. Last September, Ubide declared <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-09-08/citadel-s-ubide-says-us-economy-is-in-a-fragile-equlibrium>that the US economy is in a fragile equilibrium and "close to the edge," with Treasury yields the key long term indicator of the proximity of the chasm.
"Any rapid move above 5% [in long term Treasury yields] could be scary for risk assets,” added Ubide. That rate is currently 4.8%. If you're pitching monetary policy ideas, you might want to keep this in mind.

item.title: HSBC bonus worries: "They'll be allocated based on closeness to senior people"
item.description:
US banks may have announced their bonuses already </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank>, but if you work for HSBC the moment of truth has not arrived. When it comes on February 25th, it could be harsh.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/hsbc-to-cull-underperformers-as-some-bankers-face-zero-bonuses> reported last week that HSBC is both changing its basis for allocating bonuses and intending to pay some of its people no bonuses </news/banker-bonuses> at all. From now on, variable compensation at the bank will be based on an eat what you kill calculation. Kill nothing; you will earn nothing.
This sounds fair, but as we noted last week </news/hsbc-s-zero-bonuses-risk-upsetting-already-traumatised-bankers> it's not that simple. In investment banking </news/what-is-an-investment-bank> in particular, responsibility for originating deals can be unclear. HSBC has a complex origination structure involving sector specialists, product specialists and investment and corporate bankers. All will want their share.
"Many people are worried that compensation this year will not be allocated on a meritocratic basis," says one HSBC managing director </news/md-pay-investment-banks>(MD). "It's not eat what you kill here. It's eat if you're friends with the right senior people."
A spokesperson for HSBC said: “We are committed to attracting and retaining talent as part of a high-performance culture, ensuring our employees are rewarded competitively.”
Some insiders insist their apprehension is nonetheless valid. Veterans at the bank object to the ex-Citi people </news/hsbc-is-increasingly-run-by-people-who-ve-joined-from-citi> who occupy senior positions. "It's become my way or the highway," says one. Insiders point to 25+ exits from the US debt capital markets business in particular in the past few years, with some people leaving of their own volition for lesser platforms or without jobs to go to.
Unfair bonuses in the past may have triggered those exits. "There's a difference between where revenues are booked and where they're originated," claims one HSBC banker. "Some people have received preferential treatment," says another, who quit.
HSBC has hired alongside its exits. The bank added Jake Hartman from Barclays last August as head of FIG DCM; Margaret Szczerbicki joined on the US syndicate desk in December.
For all the complaints, it's also possible that bonuses at HSBC really needed to change.
In last year's bonus round, the bank paid its 135 material risk takers (typically MDs and other senior staff) an average of $1.4m each </news/hsbc-cuts-pay-for-top-bankers-and-traders-to-1-4m-amidst-ominous-bonus-rumours> in combined salary and bonus. Some of its MDs may not have been deserving of this.
HSBC announced the closure its M&A and ECM </news/hscb-closure-europe-us-job-cuts> businesses outside of Asia and the Middle East in January 2025. One senior executive subsequently told the Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/61e8d4e1-e49b-4048-9998-d33ac5f87d8e> that people had been paid despite originating no deals. If they're still there this year, they will be paid commensurate with that.

item.title: Citadel Securities' ex-head of low latency trading in APAC joins Hudson River Trading in New York
item.description:
Multiple electronic trading </news/high-frequency-trading-hiring-and-pay> firms have built up sizeable teams in Australia, </news/as-jane-street-and-other-prop-trading-firms-expand-in-asia-these-are-the-new-faces-and-new-teams#:~:text=Australia%3A%20Optiver%20and,IMC%20and%20Optiver.> but Hudson River Trading (HRT) </news/working-for-hudson-river-trading>is a notable exception. Despite this, it seems to appreciate talent in the region; it just hired a senior trader from Citadel Securities </news/2022/10/how-to-get-a-job-at-citadel> and relocated him to New York.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
David Zderic joined HRT as an algorithm developer. He spent two years at market maker Citadel Securities, where he was latterly the firm's head of APAC low latency trading based in the firm's Sydney office, home to ~90 employees. He left the firm in May 2024, 21 months ago, which would suggest that he has been on an extended gardening leave period.
Zderic also spent eight years with another market maker, IMC. </news/a-high-frequency-trading-firm-is-offering-its-interns-425k-to-come-back-as-open-ai-looms> He joined as a systems engineer initially before transitioning into a trading role. He also spent the last two years at the firm based in Chicago before moving back to Sydney with Citadel Securities.
Hudson River Trading has distanced itself from the notion that it's a pure high-frequency trading firm. Speaking on Bloomberg's Odd Lots podcast, the firm's head of AI Iain Dunning said that medium frequency strategies (held for minutes to days at a time) ar now "a big part of the business." It still has some high performing HFT teams, however; Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-01-19/jane-street-india-unit-saw-trading-gains-soar-494-before-curbs> reported that the firm's team in India made $264m in profits last year, compared to $248m at Citadel Securities and $334m at Jane Street.
Hudson River Trading's algorithm developers are led by Jesse Cohen </news/jesse-cohen-hrt>, an ex-Goldman Sachs MD who joined the firm aged 28. He is thought to be a big star at the firm, and was promoted into the role following the departure of HRT partner Oaz Nir. </news/oaz-nir>

item.title: Why Barclay’s FX salespeople should look over their shoulders
item.description:
Artificial Intelligence marches ever onward. Anthropic’s AI safety researcher quit two days ago, warning of a world in peril <https://www.forbes.com/sites/conormurray/2026/02/09/anthropic-ai-safety-researcher-warns-of-world-in-peril-in-resignation/>, and musing his pursuit of a poetry degree. For some people, however, AI is just a way to make a buck or two.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Enter Barclays’ recently launched AI chatbot, the awkwardly named BARXBot (come on - BarclAI was right there). “This tool delivers FX quotes 75% faster than the previous approach,” Barclays CEO C.S. Venkatakrishnan told analysts in the firm’s Q4 earning call yesterday.
That might be worrying. Electronification has been a big worry for traders for years – and salespeople thought they were much safer. If their work can be done 75% faster now, then they’re more at peril than they would like to admit. Back in 2024, Barclays itself said </news/fixed-income-trading-credit-electronification> that “The hybrid nature of some asset classes… Makes them structurally more challenging to trade on a platform.” That might not be the case in the future.
BARXBot is just one part of Barclays’ suite of AI tools. Venkatakrishnan noted that the bank had more than 250 of them in total, which is on par </news/macquarie-q3> with Bank of America’s suite of 270, and well behind both UBS’s and JPMorgan’s offerings. UBS alone has over 340 AI tools in active use.
Venkatakrishnan also said that the firm is “one of the largest users of Microsoft Copilot in the financial services industry,” whose adoption had saved over a million man-hours of work.

Kinexys is still hiring despite the leadership turbulence. The bank has 11 openings in Kinexys across London, Singapore and the US. In Jersey City, it's hiring a principal program manager on a salary of up to $265k.

item.title: Morning Coffee: Morgan Stanley bankers’ post-bonus shock. The nice guy banker who irritated his colleagues
item.description:
It’s never a nice time to get bad news. But if you’re in the bonus pool of a major investment bank, some times are distinctly better than others. Specifically, if something is going to happen to your employer’s share price, it is best for it to happen in January, after the equity-linked compensation is decided but before it’s converted into a specific number of shares ( this usually occurs either on the announcement date or the day on which cash bonuses are paid).
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Morgan Stanley bankers, therefore, are likely to be cursing their luck <https://www.ft.com/content/1c63983f-5ff0-4b70-ad55-7e4334f59422>. Their bonuses were announced in January and would typically have been paid last week. That would have given them a few scant days to enjoy feeling wealthy, before the bank's share price fell yesterday.
It could have been worse. The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/1c63983f-5ff0-4b70-ad55-7e4334f59422> notes that Morgan Stanley shares were down 2.4%, while Raymond James' shares were down over 8%. The decline was part of a sell-off in wealth management stocks. This appears to have been driven by the effect of a fintech company announcing the launch of an AI-based financial planning tool that appears to replicate a lot of the services provided by wealth managers and by ETrade (owned by Morgan Stanley).
Of course, the best advice that anyone – even an LLM based robo-advisor – will give you is not to look at the value of your equities on a daily basis, as the short term volatility will at best cause needless stress and at worst push you into making bad decisions. It’s true that $100,000 of Morgan Stanley stock a week ago is worth $96,000 now. But $100,000 of Morgan Stanley stock from a year ago is now worth $130k, and long term equity grants from five years ago have more than doubled during their vesting period.
And the actual outlook for Morgan Stanley is not bad at all. Early indications suggest that revenue momentum is still strong, the financial sponsors <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/goldman-sachs-ceo-says-financial-sponsors-may-boost-dealmaking-activity-2026-02-10/> may be coming back and Michael Grimes </news/michael-grimes-morgan-stanley> has returned from public service to start pitching for some massive IPOs. Even the competition from AI is not as big a deal for the bank's wealth management arm as it is for Schwab or Raymond James; Morgan Stanley has always been positioned at the higher end of the wirehouse brokerage market, where there is a little more bespoke advice, a bit more personal service and quite a bit more for clients to lose if they accidentally do something dumb because of a chatbot hallucination.
Nevertheless, this is probably the shape of things to come. As well as eating into financial jobs, AI is likely to start commodifying formerly lucrative services, with consequent effect on share prices. Perhaps it’s not only Morgan Stanley bankers who ought to be looking at this week’s news with a bit of trepidation.
Elsewhere, “doing a good job” and “being a nice guy who everyone likes” are usually the sort of characteristics you want to see in a colleague. Unless, of course, that colleague is one step above you on the promotion ladder. Then, it can get irritating.
Standard Chartered's disappearing CFO Diego De Georgi was seemingly frustrated <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-10/shock-at-standard-chartered-after-ceo-hopeful-de-giorgi-exits> into leaving by the perennially popular and well regarded Bill Winters </news/jes-staley-bill-winters-jpmorgan> at Standard Chartered, whose avuncular charm, steadfast avoidance of scandal and ability to weather difficult conditions in Asian markets had already caused Simon Cooper to lose hope in 2024. Winters reportedly told the bank's board that he “intends to stay on for longer than previously expected”, and their favourable response to this news seems to have persuaded De Georgi that if he wasn’t going to get the top job, he might as well play second fiddle in the considerably more lucrative orchestra at Apollo.
It’s in many ways a nice problem for the Standard Chartered board to have, but it will become a problem over time. The bank's share price fell 5% on the announcement of De Georgi’s departure. That might be because analysts tend to assume that CFOs don’t leave two weeks before a set of results if they’re going to be good news, but it’s also going to reflect the fact that the bank now has a succession management problem. It’s hard to recruit top talent into a job where the promotion path is closed off, and Winters has yet to master the Jamie Dimon trick of keeping people hanging around for “five more years”.
Meanwhile …
After several years and a compliance near-miss in 2021, McKinsey has finally decided that running a $20billion private hedge fund for its partners doesn’t have quite as many synergies with management consulting as it had hoped. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-10/mckinsey-hands-over-its-20-billion-investment-arm-to-neuberger>)
Investors are beginning to get suspicious of tech valuations, and more interested in looking at “AI-immune” sectors. Which means that the food, utilities and mining analysts are finally beginning to get a bit of airtime with clients. (FT <https://www.ft.com/content/577b97f6-2416-48b9-9bd3-717bb202ca71>)
“In the context of the profound and demanding transformation of our company, we are paying particular attention to this”. Slavomir Krupa at SocGen is dealing with an employee survey which appears to suggest that the transformation program is weighing heavy on employees; optimism, trust in top management and pride in working there are all down. (Bloomberg <https://In%20the%20context%20of%20the%20profound%20and%20demanding%20transformation%20of%20our%20company,%20we%20are%20paying%20particular%20attention%20to%20this>)
The literal meaning of “nepo” is “nephew”, but Aaron Weitman of CastleKnight Management appears to be doing pretty well independently of his famous uncle, David Tepper. (Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/david-teppers-nephew-has-a-hedge-fund-heres-how-its-doing-3b722af1>)
Although Ken Griffin complained last week that CEOs were finding it tedious to spend their time sucking up to successive administrations, Goldman Sachs’ David Solomon is built different, and can always spare some time in an interview to talk about how great the President’s pro-growth policies are going to be. (FT <https://www.ft.com/content/f443b4a1-2efd-4481-82b3-5467cf5f81e5>)
Rajeev Misra used to be famous for taking meetings barefoot, and for making huge bets at the SoftBank Vision Fund, some of which worked well and some less so. He’s always been at the cutting edge of new trends, though, so it is interesting to see that he’s pivoting his own investment vehicle away from private credit and towards investments in natural resources. (Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-10/rajeev-misra-ramps-up-private-equity-bets-as-softbank-scars-fade>)
Traditional futures trading desks have tended to enforce quite strict separation between the activities of “market making” and “trading like a complete chump”. But prediction markets, at least while the SuperBowl is being played, let you combine the two. (WSJ <https://www.wsj.com/business/media/super-bowl-prediction-betting-1302feda>)

item.title: The traders at risk of being lapped in the AI race
item.description:
Today was Macquarie’s Q3 results day, for the period from October to December 2025 (basically, everyone else’s Q4). While the commodities and global markets (CGM) group posted revenue that was “substantially up” on last year, there was something more worrying nestled in the accounts.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
The Australian bank noted that its higher revenue was “partially offset by higher operating expenses” driven by investments in the CGM platform. What were those investments exactly? Presumably nothing related to AI. The firm noted that it had just 20 or so active AI use cases implemented within CGM, and another 30 in the pipeline.
That is not a lot. During a call with analysts in Q3 last year, UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti noted that the bank had 340 live AI use cases across the entire bank, which were busy making “meaningful gains in efficiency and productivity”.
UBS is hardly an outlier. In March 2025, the New York Post reported <https://nypost.com/2025/03/14/business/jpmorgan-credits-coding-assistant-tool-for-boosting-engineers-efficiency/> that JPMorgan had around 450 potential AI use cases in the works, and that the bank was expecting that number to reach 1,000 by “next year”. That is, this year.
Bank of America also noted during its investor day <https://investor.bankofamerica.com/events-and-presentations/investor-day> in November last year that it had more than “270 AI & machine learning models”, on top of its more than 1,500 AI & machine learning granted patents. Whatever number you pick, Macquarie’s offering seems a bit scant.
Macquarie’s investment bank, MacCap, also did well. The bank credited investment-related income from asset realization, as well as private credit for the success, while noting “lower fee and commission income.” It also noted its plan was to invest in “accelerating research with advanced AI tools”, without disclosing and use cases numbers.

item.title: Deep down in the UBS MD list
item.description:
Late last week, UBS announced its managing directors for 2026. <https://www.ubs.com/global/en/careers.html?sprinklrpostid=100009701149326#md> They were not so many: 155 people there were promoted, down from 208 in the crazy days of 2021. </news/ubs-md-list>
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
In the preamble to this year's list, UBS said the geographic dispersal of its new MDs reflected its regional growth ambitions. Accordingly, while 43 people in the new UBS MD class are in Switzerland, 40 are in Asia, and only 36 are each in the Americas and Europe.
Who were they? We've belatedly added the full list below. Here, too, is some detail.
UBS promoted an array of AI experts
We are in an AI age and UBS has been promoting its AI people. Its promotions include Antoine Bechault in Switzerland, who says he's "transforming group finance through AI driven strategy," Umish Mohite, the asset management CTO lead for cloud and AI, and Musa Parmaksiz who is found in the "AI Center of Excellence."
Tangentially, UBS also promoted Sameer Bakshi, CEO of the finance function where the AI strategy is being implemented.
UBS promoted a few financial sponsors and leveraged finance bankers
Last summer UBS reorganised its financial sponsors </news/ubs-s-m-and-a-bankers-had-a-bad-quarter-but-someone-s-getting-paid> and M&A teams into a single group while surprisingly (to some) letting none of its financial sponsors bankers go.
Last week, UBS promoted some more sponsors bankers in the form of Darren Kirke in Australia, and Andrew Emmett and Tomas Dicpinigaitis in New York.
Also promoted was Kanika Chaudhry in leveraged debt capital markets in London. And John Yiannoullou, a former financing banker who's now global banking COO for the Americas.
UBS promoted some M&A loyalists
Various M&A bankers were promoted alongside financial sponsors bankers. Many have been at the Swiss bank for years.
In London, they included Aamer Bhatti a who's been there since 2019 after joining from Warwick Business School, and Meera Sheff, who's been there since 2011. In the US, they included Whitney Mikell, a real estate, lodging and leisure banker who joined in 2012.
We didn't spy many ex-Credit Suisse bankers among the new MDs, except for Emil Strand, who appeared in the New York industrials group via Credit Suisse in 2023.
UBS promoted ahead of the hoped-for recovery in IPOs
2025 was not a good year for IPOs but UBS nonetheless promoted Clara Comellini in EMEA equity capital markets, plus Marco Guarino, its head of EMEA equity syndicate and Rajan Sharma, its head of syndicate in Asia. Peter Castoro, the New York based head of healthcare ECM, who was hired from JPMorgan last August, is on the list too.
A scattering of equity researchers made cut, including Josh Spector, a chemicals researcher in New York and Daniel Major, a metals and mining analyst in London. Contrary to speculation by some, Rory McKenzie, head of businesses services research, wasn't promoted. McKenzie's wife, Helen Brand is the deputy head of EMEA research, but McKenzie has an entirely separate reporting line.
UBS promoted various Asian bankers
UBS's Asian bankers are understood to have received its highest bonus increases </news/everything-we-know-about-2026-bonuses-by-bank> this year. Its recent Asia-based MD promotions include Fabrice Delacroix, the head of Asian renewables banking, Chaoxiang Jia in Hong Kong and Tra Zboinski, the head of Vietnam coverage.
UBS promoted its head of US ETF trading and senior quants
In equities, the promotions include Kudzai Ndondo, the head of Americas EFT trading, Ciprian Ticula, the head of US equity quants and Davide Montoni, the head of Americas quantitative investment strategies and equity derivative sales. In Europe, UBS promoted François-Xavier Lefèvre, its EMEA head of equity derivative flow sales.
In China UBS promoted Jun Yin, its Shanghai-based head of electronic trading.
Where were the promotions in fixed income trading?
UBS MD promotions seemed most sparse in fixed income sales and trading. Andrew Sugden in FX options trading was promoted, as was Paul Buttenmueller, the Singapore-based global head of eFX trading.
However, we didn't see any promotions on the London rates desk, which has lost various people </news/ubs-markets-bonuses> and doesn't seem inclined to replace them internally. "Everyone is too junior or too new," observes one insider.

item.title: How to get a job in venture capital
item.description:
Technically speaking, venture capital is a subset of private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity>: like big private equity (PE) firms, venture capital firms invested in companies that aren't publicly traded on a stock exchange. But working for a VC firm is a wildly different experience to a career in the likes of Blackstone </news/blackstone-pay-london> or Carlyle. </news/pay-carlyle-private-equity> This week was the LSE Alternate Investments Conference (AIC) where professionals from various private markets industries educate students on their respective fields. Multiple VC professionals told students about the work you'll do in venture capital and the traits you'll need to possess to thrive in it.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
What is venture capital?
Venture capital firms traditionally invest in early-stage companies, taking a minor ownership stake alongside various other investors. Traditional PE firms, by contrast, tend to invest in more mature companies, and take majority stakes in their portfolio companies. PE firms tend to have more specialisation, at least on a fund-by-fund basis, while VCs are more generalist.
The biggest difference between VCs and PE firms, though, is the level of support they claim to provide for founders. Luke Pappas, partner at New Enterprise Associates, said at the AIC that VC is all about "look[ing] for the secret sauce in the founding team" and having "conviction that this team is going to be the one to change things." That conviction is necessary because "all the companies we're interested in are inherently unprofitable for the first few years."
VCs have a reputation for inflating the valuations of their portfolio companies. Pappas said "many of my hedge fund </news/all-the-jobs-in-hedge-funds> friends and private equity </news/private-equity-job-titles>friends will ping me and tell me that we're not very rational in our pricing." He said that many of the best investments in VC are blink-and-you'll-miss-it, however, and that accepting an inflated valuation is necessary; "if this company ultimately becomes a $10bn company in the long run, it won't matter much."
Fundraising in VC isn't what it used to be, however. A report <https://carta.com/data/resources/state-of-startups-2025/> from accounting infrastructure firm Carta estimated that there was a total of $110bn in startup investments through its platform last year, down from a high of $220.3bn in 2021. The Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/investing/u-s-venture-capital-fundraising-falls-35-as-firms-stay-private-longer-601d6629?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqcmJtMGn0708IAAmI57STH_eJb-ZpWCi2dm2FEv_voBf6NEOr6LmFjk3u3X87w%3D&gaa_ts=698b69de&gaa_sig=ALXM_v5jL_2zYlZQYKuVxfcSXddtxZ2L-MRAnKSn21V__rbOS6mYZkhHRON4aBo2_63ubQv_vi3c6UbTgj-ZZA%3D%3D> reported last month that fundraising for US VC firms in 2025 was the lowest it had been for six years. Funds have a lot less margin for error, which is putting increased pressure on VC professionals.
What do you do in venture capital?
"VC's are not glamorous," said Antler partner Hannah Leach at the AIC. "It's honestly a lot of admin." You'll be sitting in numerous meetings for your portfolio companies and researching new ones. Leach said "you need to be adept at sending a cold email </news/finance/cold-email-investment-banking-job>" if you want to win new business.
Your job is to see through the noise in the startup world. Pappas said that "every day, I open up my news app and see 15 different products that people say are changing the world." Leach said that VC is all about doing your homework and "go[ing] into conversations well-informed regardless of asset class."
Cherry Ventures principal Nadja Reischel said that you have to look for "founders who are super obsessed with the product," as that obsession will carry them through the next ten years of working in their startup. You'll also need to gauge their learning speed and commercial instinct; "you want people who are talking to not 20 but 2,000 potential customers," Reischel said.
All of this typically translates to long hours. Leach said that "work-life balance doesn't quite exist in VC... you need to want to get up at 7am and work through to midnight." Reischel said that "venture is pretty much 24/7" and suggested that she hasn't taken a Sunday off since she joined her firm.
What skills and experience are VC firms looking for?
To succeed in VC, you need to be a people person, but there's more to it than that.
Pappas said that you're a good fit for VC if your "brain likes to context switch a lot of times," as you'll be working across a wide range of products and teams. Leach said you also "need to be good at psychology." We recently held an AMA <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/t/ama-im-the-managing-director-of-newton-venture-program-a-vc-education-program/4767> with Shayan Roy Chowdhury, MD of VC education platform, the Newton Venture Program; he said that the most important skills are "critical thinking, ability to think big, relationship building, time management, and clarity of communication."
As with their founders, VC firms also want their employees to be passionate. Pappas said that, if you're not, "there's going to be 1,000 people who are genuinely interested and they will outperform you." Leach said that demonstrating your passion is particularly hard as a graduate, but suggested building a "shadow portfolio of companies you think will do very well" to stand out.
Having a financial background isn't always necessary. Speaking at the AIC in 2024, LocalGlobe partner Mish Mashkautsan said "template paths" like banking or consulting </news/pay-mckinsey-bain-bcg-big-four> are "uninspiring" as routes into VC. Instead, he said "the best thing you can do is take a bet on yourself." Chowdhury said in our AMA that many people join VCs after working in a startup in a role like a founder's associate </news/the-most-exciting-and-bizarre-job-for-24-year-olds-at-revolut-and-other-fintechs> or chief of staff. One ex-banker in VC previously told us </news/2020/11/how-to-move-out-of-banking-and-into-venture-capital> that big name brands are much more important for getting a VC job in Europe than they are in America.
What jobs are available in VC?
Unlike PE, most venture capital firms do not have robust intern or graduate recruitment programs. There are exceptions, like Bessemer Ventures' analyst program, but, you'll likely have to monitor the recruiting pages of the firms you're interested in.
There aren't that many VC jobs available, even at the top firms. Andreessen Horowitz, for example, is one of the largest firms but only has 23 current openings. Y Combinator, another major VC, has just five openings. Sequoia Capital has no current openings. Roles in VC are extremely oversubscribed, so you'll need to rely on connections where possible. If you're a right fit for the people-centric world of VC, that shouldn't be hard.
How much do VC jobs pay?
A recent salary survey <https://www.newcomer.co/p/heres-what-your-fellow-venture-capitalists?utm_source=substack&publication_id=82416&post_id=186864407&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share> from Venture5 found that analysts in VC earn $80k on average. You'll earn $130k-150k as an associate, ~$200k as a mid-level professional, </news/2023/01/venture-capitalism-jobs> then over $300k on average if you can make partner.
A key appeal of working in PE (and thus VC) is the opportunity to earn carried interest, </news/what-is-carried-interest> which is a percentage of the profits should a portfolio company have a large enough exit. Only 24% of analysts reported that they earned carry, however.
As a partner, pay depends on how large your fund is. The survey found that partners at VC funds with more than $500bn in AUM earned $585k in total compensation. When AUM was $250-500bn, average compensation was $402k.

Fundraising in VC isn't what it used to be, however. A report <https://carta.com/data/resources/state-of-startups-2025/> from accounting infrastructure firm Carta estimated that there was a total of $110bn in startup investments through its platform last year, down from a high of $220.3bn in 2021. The Wall Street Journal <https://www.wsj.com/finance/investing/u-s-venture-capital-fundraising-falls-35-as-firms-stay-private-longer-601d6629?gaa_at=eafs&gaa_n=AWEtsqcmJtMGn0708IAAmI57STH_eJb-ZpWCi2dm2FEv_voBf6NEOr6LmFjk3u3X87w%3D&gaa_ts=698b69de&gaa_sig=ALXM_v5jL_2zYlZQYKuVxfcSXddtxZ2L-MRAnKSn21V__rbOS6mYZkhHRON4aBo2_63ubQv_vi3c6UbTgj-ZZA%3D%3D> reported last month that fundraising for US VC firms in 2025 was the lowest it had been for six years. Funds have a lot less margin for error, which is putting increased pressure on VC professionals.
What do you do in venture capital?
"VC's are not glamorous," said Antler partner Hannah Leach at the AIC. "It's honestly a lot of admin." You'll be sitting in numerous meetings for your portfolio companies and researching new ones. Leach said "you need to be adept at sending a cold email </news/finance/cold-email-investment-banking-job>" if you want to win new business.
Your job is to see through the noise in the startup world. Pappas said that "every day, I open up my news app and see 15 different products that people say are changing the world." Leach said that VC is all about doing your homework and "go[ing] into conversations well-informed regardless of asset class."
Cherry Ventures principal Nadja Reischel said that you have to look for "founders who are super obsessed with the product," as that obsession will carry them through the next ten years of working in their startup. You'll also need to gauge their learning speed and commercial instinct; "you want people who are talking to not 20 but 2,000 potential customers," Reischel said.
All of this typically translates to long hours. Leach said that "work-life balance doesn't quite exist in VC... you need to want to get up at 7am and work through to midnight." Reischel said that "venture is pretty much 24/7" and suggested that she hasn't taken a Sunday off since she joined her firm.
What skills and experience are VC firms looking for?
To succeed in VC, you need to be a people person, but there's more to it than that.
Pappas said that you're a good fit for VC if your "brain likes to context switch a lot of times," as you'll be working across a wide range of products and teams. Leach said you also "need to be good at psychology." We recently held an AMA <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/t/ama-im-the-managing-director-of-newton-venture-program-a-vc-education-program/4767> with Shayan Roy Chowdhury, MD of VC education platform, the Newton Venture Program; he said that the most important skills are "critical thinking, ability to think big, relationship building, time management, and clarity of communication."
As with their founders, VC firms also want their employees to be passionate. Pappas said that, if you're not, "there's going to be 1,000 people who are genuinely interested and they will outperform you." Leach said that demonstrating your passion is particularly hard as a graduate, but suggested building a "shadow portfolio of companies you think will do very well" to stand out.
Having a financial background isn't always necessary. Speaking at the AIC in 2024, LocalGlobe partner Mish Mashkautsan said "template paths" like banking or consulting </news/pay-mckinsey-bain-bcg-big-four> are "uninspiring" as routes into VC. Instead, he said "the best thing you can do is take a bet on yourself." Chowdhury said in our AMA that many people join VCs after working in a startup in a role like a founder's associate </news/the-most-exciting-and-bizarre-job-for-24-year-olds-at-revolut-and-other-fintechs> or chief of staff. One ex-banker in VC previously told us </news/2020/11/how-to-move-out-of-banking-and-into-venture-capital> that big name brands are much more important for getting a VC job in Europe than they are in America.
What jobs are available in VC?
Unlike PE, most venture capital firms do not have robust intern or graduate recruitment programs. There are exceptions, like Bessemer Ventures' analyst program, but, you'll likely have to monitor the recruiting pages of the firms you're interested in.
There aren't that many VC jobs available, even at the top firms. Andreessen Horowitz, for example, is one of the largest firms but only has 23 current openings. Y Combinator, another major VC, has just five openings. Sequoia Capital has no current openings. Roles in VC are extremely oversubscribed, so you'll need to rely on connections where possible. If you're a right fit for the people-centric world of VC, that shouldn't be hard.
How much do VC jobs pay?
A recent salary survey <https://www.newcomer.co/p/heres-what-your-fellow-venture-capitalists?utm_source=substack&publication_id=82416&post_id=186864407&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share> from Venture5 found that analysts in VC earn $80k on average. You'll earn $130k-150k as an associate, ~$200k as a mid-level professional, </news/2023/01/venture-capitalism-jobs> then over $300k on average if you can make partner.
A key appeal of working in PE (and thus VC) is the opportunity to earn carried interest, </news/what-is-carried-interest> which is a percentage of the profits should a portfolio company have a large enough exit. Only 24% of analysts reported that they earned carry, however.
As a partner, pay depends on how large your fund is. The survey found that partners at VC funds with more than $500bn in AUM earned $585k in total compensation. When AUM was $250-500bn, average compensation was $402k.

item.title: Everything we know about the 2026 bonus round, by bank
item.description:
How was your bonus </news/banker-bonuses> for last year? If you're at a European bank, excepting UBS </news/ubs-markets-bonuses> and Barclays, </news/barclays-bonuses-2026> you may not know yet. Nor will you know if you are with the Japanese. If you're at a US bank and you were paid up by less than 10%, then bad luck.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
The general verdict is that this year's bonus round has been good, but that it might have been better. "Expectations did not match reality as all bankers expected to be highly compensated at all levels and this was not the case," says Mike Karp, CEO and founder of search firm Options Group. In sales and trading </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank>, Karp says some people did "very well indeed." However, traders say this year's bonuses were even more heavily skewed towards performance than usual.
Within sales and trading, macro traders had a particularly strong 2025, with most US banks citing strong growth in macro revenues in the fourth quarter. Macro bonus pools are thought to to be up 8-12% as a result. Credit bonuses are understood to be less strong, with pools up 5-10% or less.
Below is what we know on bonuses by bank. This has not been validated by the banks concerned, who typically do not comment on compensation. If you have anything to add, please add a comment, or venture into the Bubble <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/>where discussion is free.
Bank of America bonuses
Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-06/goldman-jpmorgan-bankers-see-bonus-pools-rise-at-least-10> says BofA's bonus pool was up 10% this year. However, top ranked associates at Bank of America say they received bonuses </news/bank-of-america-associates-got-their-bonuses-and-they-feel-nostalgic>equivalent to 75% of salaries and that this was disappointing as they were receiving 110% not so long ago. BofA associates </news/banks-weird-hierarchies-analysts-associates-vps-mds> also complain that they are receiving 30% of their bonuses in stock that vests over a four year period.
In December, Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/sustainability/boards-policy-regulation/bofa-bonuses-will-jump-investment-bankers-this-year-sources-say-2025-12-19/> reported that BofA intended to increase bonuses by 20% for its investment bankers. Asia-based bonuses are thought to have come closest to this approximation. BofA's markets bonuses </news/bank-of-america-bonuses-are-out-they-may-be-moderately-good> are thought to have been up by less. There has been some griping <https://efinancialcareers.com/news/at-bank-of-america-some-equities-traders-would-like-bigger-bonuses#:~:text=BofA's%20equities%20insiders%20say%20they,under-compensated%20relative%20to%20workload.> in areas like EMEA equities (and particularly in equity research), where insiders say they exceeded their 2025 budget in September but received bonus increases of only a few percentage points. There are suggestions that the EMEA markets business helped subsidize the US this year.
Barclays bonuses
Today is bonus day at Barclays. As we reported earlier </news/barclays-bonuses-2026>, 1,465 senior staff categorised as material risk takers at the British bank received a 16% increase in their average bonus to £900k ($1.2m). Barclays' remaining 91,500 staff may not have done badly either: Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-10/barclays-lifts-bonus-pool-across-bank-by-15-to-2-2-billlion?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260210&utm_campaign=author_21061455>notes that bonuses across the bank are up 15% and that many junior staff received £500 share awards.
All this sounds positive, but some people at Barclays seem to be whinging all the same. Maybe the pool was skewed towards the 718 people paid over €1m, and the 89 of them paid over €4m.
BNP Paribas bonuses
BNP Paribas has not announced its bonuses yet. The French bank doesn't break out compensation spending in its corporate and investment bank, but operating expenses in the division rose only 3% last year and fell in the final quarter when bonuses are typically calibrated.
While none of this bodes well, </news/bnp-q4-2025>Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-06/bnp-paribas-considers-raising-trader-bonus-pool-by-close-to-10> reported last week that BNP Paribas is considering increases bonuses in its markets division by 10%.
Last year, the average bonus </news/bnp-paribas-bonuses> for material risk takers at the French bank's CIB was €678k. This year, senior BNP traders could cautiously budget for €750k. M&A bankers will seemingly get less.
Citi bonuses
Citi bonuses have been "mixed," say insiders. This is the nature of the beast, but at Citi some factors have contributed to this.
At the top end in London, Citi invited its material risk takers (MDs and other senior people) to sign new contracts </news/citi-salaries-london> at the end of last year. These contracts locked in small salaries and larger bonuses, adding a greater element of variability to pay. Financial News <https://www.fnlondon.com/articles/citigroup-hikes-bonuses-for-london-dealmakers-by-up-to-15-1388b8ed> reported that some London bankers then received bonus hikes of 10-15% and that some got 20%.
Not everyone was treated this generously though. In the markets business, some Citi traders have complained of being zeroed </news/citi-cutting-jobs-bonuses> and having bonuses halved. Citi is cutting jobs and there are suggestions that swathes of people were intentionally disappointed in the hope that they might leave of their own accords.
Deutsche Bank bonuses
Deutsche Bank doesn't announce bonuses until March, by which time it will have been able to take good stock of how much everyone else is paying. Last year, it paid material risk takers average bonuses of $1.1m </news/barclays-hsbc-deutsche-bank-bnp-paribas-socgen-ubs-pay> and the bonus pool for investment bankers and traders rose by 32%. <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2025-03-13/deutsche-bank-boosts-bonus-pool-to-2-5-billion-most-since-2014>
Goldman Sachs bonuses
People at Goldman are understood to be variably happy. Goldman bankers are understood to be happiest of all, markets professionals quite happy, and middle and back office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking>staff ambivalent-to-sad.
One senior technologist at Goldman told us </news/goldman-sachs-and-morgan-stanley-people-complain-of-poor-bonuses-away-from-the-front-office> engineering and operations </news/operations-jobs-banking> bonuses were "hit badly" in a possible attempt to encourage people to leave. Overall, Bloomberg says the pool at Goldman was 10% higher.
HSBC bonuses
HSBC won't announce bonuses until later this month, but things do not sound promising. Bloomberg reported last week </news/hsbc-s-zero-bonuses-risk-upsetting-already-traumatised-bankers> that the bank is planning to allocate zeroes and to an operate an eat what you kill model. There is apprehension internally about what this will entail.
JPMorgan bonuses
JPMorgan bonuses are understood to have been "good". Bloomberg says JPMorgan's pool was also 10% up.
Morgan Stanley bonuses
Morgan Stanley is understood </news/goldman-sachs-and-morgan-stanley-people-complain-of-poor-bonuses-away-from-the-front-office> to have paid its bankers well, especially in Asia, but there have been simultaneous complaints of poor pay in the middle and back office, where some staff are claiming that they've been shifted onto a salary heavy structure without any appreciable increase in salary.
UBS bonuses
UBS has yet to publish details of the bonuses it paid "key risk takers" for last year, but early indications are that people were mostly happy. Everyone we have spoken to said bonuses were "fine," </news/ubs-markets-bonuses> with double digit increases in the markets pool being mooted. Bloomberg <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-05/ubs-investment-bank-units-to-see-bonus-pools-jump-by-up-to-20>reported that some units saw 20% increases in the bonus pool and that UBS's Asian banking bonuses were up 18%.

item.title: How a $20bn private equity firm gets by with less than 80 people
item.description:
You don’t need a big team to manage a lot of money. Just look at some of the world’s littlest tiniest hedge funds </news/small-hedge-funds>, which manage tens of billion of dollars of capital. And it’s not a phenomenon limited to the hedge fund </news/how-to-get-a-hedge-fund-job> world, either.
Click here to join the bubble by eFinancialCareers, our new anonymous community. <https://bubble.efinancialcareers.com/login?_gl=1*ut8n6u*_gcl_au*MTg4MDY2NTExNi4xNzYxNTU3NDIz*_ga*ODczNzI2NTA0LjE3NTM2OTk2ODI.*_ga_NZFQV4MXPM*czE3NjM2NDM0MDYkbzI1NiRnMSR0MTc2MzY0MzQzOSRqMjckbDAkaDMyMjc4OTUzMw..>✍️
Speaking at the LSE’s Alternative Investments Conference, Kate Stewart – a VP in the investments team of private equity </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-private-equity> firm Pantheon Ventures – laid out the firm’s structure for students interested in working at the firm.
Stewart explained that Pantheon, whose private equity arm manages $20bn in assets, employs an investment team of less than 80 people, spread across six global offices: London, New York, Chicago, San Francisco, Hong Kong, and Singapore.
Interestingly, the composition of those 79 people is rather… Top heavy. Pantheon employs 15 Partner tier in its PE team, 6 managing directors (MDs), and 6 Principals (Director-level professionals). Less than half of its team are actual number crunchers, including 11 VPs, 9 senior associates, and around 7/8 associates and analysts.
That’s very different to how a bigger company would structure its headcount. At Deutsche Bank </news/deutsche-bank-juniors-say-they-re-being-suffocated-by-a-surfeit-of-m-ds> in London, for example, professionals of director rank and above make up 29% of headcount – at Pantheon, that number is 35%. Managing director and above are 8% of Deutsche Bank’s London office, compared to 27% at Pantheon.
Of course, Pantheon’s figures only include its investment team. Stewart also noted that it had numerous other teams dedicated to investor relations, as well as “dedicated teams focused on deal structuring, tax structuring and sustainability” that weren’t counted. And that’s not to mention a “large back office </news/front-office-middle-office-back-office-banking> which focus on areas like legal, compliance </news/how-to-get-a-job-in-compliance>, finance </news/accounting-job-finance-banking>.”
What does that sort of throughput lead to? Well, since 2014, Pantheon has raised $12bn in capital, screened over 3,000 funds, and currently holds over 500 advisory seats. The firm has also made over 1,000 commitments (investments) since 1992.

item.title: G-Research veteran swaps electronic trading for AI sports analytics
item.description:
Electronic trading </news/best-electronic-trading-for-to-work-for> engineers are experts in low latency systems, which can make them very valuable outside of finance. After just shy of two decades at one of London's largest trading firms, a senior engineer </news/how-to-get-a-technology-job-bank> has opted to work in motorsports instead.
Follow eFinancialCareers on Google News here. <https://news.google.com/publications/CAAqMggKIixDQklTR3dnTWFoY0tGV1ZtYVc1aGJtTnBZV3hqWVhKbFpYSnpMbU52YlNnQVAB?ceid=GB:en&oc=3>
Chris Ramshaw is joining PACETEQ GmbH as its head of software. According to his LinkedIn, he spent 17 years at G-Research </news/g-research-pay>, predominantly as a software development manager after joining from Citi. Later in his tenure, he also worked in operations analysis and became the principal customer representative for its trading platform.
Paceteq was co-founded by F1 quant pioneer Neil Martin, formerly head strategist for Ferrari. It focuses on providing real-time data insights for motorsports using AI, with plans to expand into more sports, including cycling and football </news/2023/09/football-to-banking>.
Ramshaw is a bit of an outlier in that other senior hires tend to already be in the world of motorsports. In October, for example, it hired Albert Lau as a VP of product; he was most recently chief engineer for NEOM McLaren's Formula E racing team.

item.title: Morning Coffee: JPMorgan's rebellious employees now meek and compliant. Abrupt exit of Standard Chartered CFO for something better
item.description:
As the many complaints </news/the-fca-had-another-awkward-townhall-about-returning-to-the-office> about returning to the office </news/2023/02/back-to-the-office-banking-and-finance> 50% of the time at the UK Financial Conduct Authority show, homeworking is a popular thing and attempting to get people back into the office can prompt insurrection.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
The sound and the fury may pass, though. At JPMorgan, where people are now in the office five days a week </news/jpmorgan-return-to-office-five-days> and employees initially complained <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/jpmorgan-employees-gripe-about-dimons-return-to-office-edict-2023-04-27/> that management was "tone deaf" and divisive, the complaining has fizzled out.
The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/f1f95f01-bd05-4a92-9222-4ddd3d356bb1> reports that only 2,000 of JPMorgan's 300,000 global employees have signed a petition against homeworking; less than 1% of the total. This time last year, the petition had 1,200 signatures. Growth is not exponential.
The remaining 99% of non-signatories are either happy to be in the office five days a week or quietly resigned to their fates. One of them tells the FT it would be "career suicide" to publicly complain. This is not irrational. When the petition was launched, JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon publicly declared, </news/jamie-dimon-work-from-home-jpmorgan> “Don’t waste time on it … I don’t care how many people sign that f—ing petition.” Last year, Nicholas Welch, <https://nypost.com/2025/03/25/business/jpmorgan-analyst-who-slammed-jamie-dimon-over-rto-is-apparently-author-of-reddit-rants-against-ceo/> a technology support analyst at JPMorgan was fired and then rehired for publicly challenging the return to office mandate. Welch was subsequently outed for posting rants against Dimon on Reddit (now deleted <https://www.reddit.com/r/JPMorganChase/comments/1jium04/hey_there_uncle_jamie/>) and his whereabouts is unknown.
The suppression of return to office whinging is not the same as people joyfully sitting at their desks, though. At banks like SocGen </news/soc-gen-insiders-say-there-was-an-awkward-townhall-about-returning-to-the-office>, where people are now expected in the office four days a week, employees have taken to calling CEO Slawomir Krupa "Captain Krupa" in an act of minor defiance. Last June, Krupa declared that “people on a screen” were “not part of meetings”, the FT notes.
Separately, Mark Mason is stepping down as Citi CFO, but he is doing so in incremental steps over a four month period. Diego De Giorgi is also stepping down at Standard Chartered, but he is doing so immediately.
De Giorgi is going to Apollo, where he will be head of Europe. Standard Chartered announced <https://www.sc.com/en/press-release/appointment-of-peter-burrill-as-interim-group-chief-financial-officer/> De Giorgi's unexpected leap at 5am this morning and said he is going with "immediate effect." Reuters <https://www.reuters.com/business/finance/standard-chartered-names-peter-burrill-interim-cfo-2026-02-10/> notes that Standard Chartered's shares fell 4.1% at the open. De Giorgi was expected to replace Standard Chartered CEO Bill Winters. Now he's found something better instead.
Meanwhile...
Marc Rowan at Apollo says the group will outpeform rivals in the future as it didn't invest in software companies hit by concerns about AI. “I expect that we will be, along with a handful of other managers, prettier than we have been historically.” (Financial Times) <https://www.ft.com/content/7302e0ba-43a5-4e46-8d23-c98bb7ced025>
Everyone wants to work in secondaries, says Todd Miller at Jefferies. "It's a very hot industry. Everyone's trying to get into this space. I get a massive amount of inbounds on LinkedIn. I've had kids writing to me on LinkedIn out of college, sophomores at elite schools. They want to do this job."(Business Insider) <https://www.businessinsider.com/investment-banking-advising-secondaries-became-hottest-job-wall-street-2026-2>
To hit its new targets, Barclays said it will make efficiency savings of about £2 billion, adding to the £700 million made last year. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-10/barclays-vows-to-hand-15-billion-to-investors-after-profit-beat?utm_medium=email&utm_source=author_alert&utm_term=260210&utm_campaign=author_21061455>
Bankers are disappointed with bonuses. “People have amnesia. They remember how good it was towards the end of the year, but forget the market discombobulation in the first three months.” (Financial News) <https://www.fnlondon.com/amp/articles/bankers-feeling-short-changed-by-bonus-round-after-deal-surge-b82a0ff8>
"I have yet to set Claude loose on Deutsche Bank. But as a first attempt, it proved remarkably capable." (Marc Rubenstein) <https://www.netinterest.co/p/excel-forever?utm_source=substack&publication_id=43559&post_id=187111221&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&utm_campaign=email-share&triggerShare=true&isFreemail=true&r=qrn8&triedRedirect=true>
Morgan Stanley junior points out the uses of AI: “We have hundreds upon hundreds of deal folders, with decades of models and analysis and PowerPoints, and truly everything you do in banking could be aided by finding precedent analysis. If you have a good precedent, your life becomes much easier.” (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-09/young-bankers-embrace-ai-at-morgan-stanley-and-bank-of-america?taid=6989ce291a905e000123acd5&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>
Singapore stopped being cool. (Marginal Revolution) <https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2026/02/why-is-singapore-no-longer-cool.html>
The trouble with jobs in private equity: "Junior guys hustle to find deals while senior guys decide which ones they like without being close enough to make the right decisions. This frustrates the junior guys, who do all the work. It's a cycle where junior guys eventually do their own thing, and senior guys bring in new people, repeating the process." (X) <https://x.com/_inpractise/status/2020510698803995041/photo/1>
Co-Chief Executive Officers Doug Ostrover and Marc Lipschultz pledged more than half of their Blue Owl stakes to secure loans, but value of their collateral fell $260m as Blue Owl shares have slumped. A margin call could make things far worse. (Bloomberg) <https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2026-02-09/blue-owl-founders-pledged-1-9-billion-stake-before-stock-plunge?taid=6989f4408b8bdb00018c6da1&utm_campaign=trueanthem&utm_content=business&utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter>

item.title: Barclays' bonuses now £900k for MDs, despite poor year for bankers
item.description:
Barclays managing directors (MDs), most of whom are categorised as material risk takers, are being rewarded generously for their efforts last year.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Filings <https://home.barclays/content/dam/home-barclays/documents/investor-relations/ResultAnnouncements/FullYear2025Results/FY25-BPLC-Pillar-3.pdf>accompanying the British bank's fourth quarter results show that material risk takers at Barclays' investment bank </news/what-is-an-investment-bank> received their highest bonuses, </news/banker-bonuses> on average, for six years in compensation for 2025. This was despite a feeble year for its investment bankers.
Barclays employs 1,465 material risk takers in its investment bank and it paid them a total of £732m ($1m) in bonuses, or £901k each. Six years ago, the average bonus for Barclays' MRTs was £557k.
Barclays investment bank MRTs also received salaries averarging £652k, leading to a total package of £1.6m.
Barclays' generosity followed a feeble year for its bankers, in which M&A </news/get-a-job-in-ma> fees increased only 2%, equity capital markets fees fell 21% and debt capital markets </news/capital-markets-jobs-ecm-and-dcm> fees rose 1%. The bank's global share of investment banking fees fell from 3.3% in 2024 to 3% in 2025 as a result.
Despite this, Barclays continues to talk of pivoting to an advisory based model and growing its investment banking operations. By 2028, it aspires to boost its share of global investment banking fees to 3.5%.
While Barclays bankers floundered, its salespeople and traders </news/how-do-you-get-a-job-in-sales-and-trading-in-a-bank> maintained their own share of global revenues at 6.5%. Barclays said today that macro, securitised products and credit trading were strong last year, as was prime financing.
Although the average Barclays investment bank MRT (including, bankers and markets professionals) received a £900k bonus for last year, bonuses will not have been allocated equally. As the chart below shows, across the bank as a whole, bonuses were skewed towards top performers as ever last year.
762 people across the bank earned over €1 last year. Someone earned €17m-18m. 89 people at Barclays earned over €3.9m compared to 60 in 2024.

item.title: Morgan Stanley's Michael Grimes, the $10.5m salary and the $56m stock bonus
item.description:
Michael Grimes is back at Morgan Stanley. The Financial Times <https://www.ft.com/content/7d960fcc-c80f-4c12-8b8e-1fd41fc7a444>reported today that Grimes has returned from his long year in the Trump Administration.
Get Morning Coffee </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>☕ in your inbox. Sign up here. </myefc/preferences/subscribe?newsletter=network_newsletter>
Instead of simply being a managing director (MD) and co-head of technology investment banking at Morgan Stanley as he was before, Grimes will now be the bank's group chair of investment banking. In this new role, Morgan Stanley says Grimes will apply his expertise to "the full banking and [institutional securities group] franchise, particularly as technology transforms productivity and impacts global industrial policy."
Now that Grimes is back in the room, it's worth remembering that he was never a standard investment banker anyway. In the public financial disclosure report <https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25969697-grimes-michael-d-278e278t-2025/> that Grimes filed when he joined the government in 2025, he revealed a $10.5m Morgan Stanley salary and $56m of Morgan Stanley bonuses that had been deferred during the previous three years. By comparison, H1B Visa filings suggest the average salary for an MD at Morgan Stanley is closer to $400k.
As we reported last April, </news/michael-grimes-banker> Grimes received other special dispensations during his 30 year career with the bank. He was, for example, permitted to avoid Morgan Stanley's management committees and firmwide strategy sessions, and encouraged to simply originate deals. He did this successfully, working on the IPOs of Facebook and Airbnb and cultivating a strong relationship with Elon Musk.
Musk is coincidentally considering a $1.5 trillion IPO for SpaceX this summer, and the FT notes that Grimes' return leaves Morgan Stanley well-placed to win a leading role. If so, Grimes' next bonus at Morgan Stanley could be far higher than his last one.
Grimes doesn't really need the money. As is always the case when bankers leave for government roles, Grimes benefited from the accelerated vesting </news/jamie-dimon-donald-trump> of his $56m of Morgan Stanley stock, which became accessible all at once instead of in three year tranches when he left for Trump. He will also have avoided capital gains tax if his deferred stock were reinvested in US treasuries or diversified funds.
Grimes wasn't really suited to government jobs. When he worked on a purge of the Chips Program Office last year, government employees complained </news/michael-grimes> of his manner and said it wasn't a "psychologically healthy place to work." Back at Morgan Stanley, Grimes can now be as brusque as he likes, so long as he delivers the SpaceX IPO.
